Doctor: Hello, I understand you were admitted to our hospital last month with left quadrant abdominal pain and weight loss for more than 6 months. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, the pain gets worse after eating, and I also experience abdominal distension, belching, and reduced flatus.
Doctor: Have you tried any treatments for these symptoms before coming here?
Patient: I was taking some traditional Chinese medicine that temporarily relieved the symptoms.
Doctor: I see. Do you have any medical history we should know about?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of hypertension, but my control has been poor.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. It looks like you underwent a colonoscopy examination in a local hospital. What were the results of that examination?
Patient: They verbally reported no pathologic findings.
Doctor: Alright, during your physical examination here, we found mesogastric tenderness and an enlarged spleen. Your blood laboratory examination reported only mild hypokalemia, and your urinary and stool reports were normal. Enhanced computerized tomography showed splenomegaly, jejunal wall edema, narrowed lumen, enlarged lymph nodes, mesenteric edema, atrophy of the right liver lobe, hypertrophy of the left and caudate lobes, calcification, and periportal fibrosis. These signs are compatible with hepatic schistosomiasis.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a condition that needs attention. During the double balloon enteroscopy, we noticed that your blood pressure was not stable, so we couldn't reexamine the colon. The upper enteroscopy showed an ulcer 150 cm distal to the Treitz ligament, measuring 3.0 x 2.0 cm. The ulcer had a white coating and peripheral mucosal hyperemia, occupying 2/3 of the lumen, making it difficult for the endoscope to pass through. We took four biopsies from the ulcer, and 20 cm proximal from the ulcer, we found many scattered irregular ulcers, from which we took two biopsies.

Doctor: Hello, I see that you've been referred to our hospital due to a mass that was incidentally discovered in your right kidney. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: The mass is 16-mm in size and located in the anterior medial position of your kidney. We performed a renal biopsy, which confirmed that it's renal cell carcinoma, a type of kidney cancer.
Patient: Oh no, that's terrible.
Doctor: I understand your concern. We have a treatment plan to address this issue. We placed a hook wire in the tumor with the help of an interventional radiologist and CT guidance.
Patient: What's the purpose of that?
Doctor: The hook wire helps us localize the tumor during surgery. It's a technique we use for nonpalpable breast lesions to facilitate intraoperative localization. We will perform a partial nephrectomy to remove the tumor.
Patient: How does the surgery work?
Doctor: You will be placed in a modified left lateral decubitus position, and we will establish pneumoperitoneum. Trocars will be placed to access your abdomen. We will mobilize your bowel medially and develop the plane between the anterior Gerota's fascia and the posterior mesocolon.
Patient: Okay, and then?
Doctor: Your kidney will be mobilized within Gerota's fascia. We will locate the hook wire and clamp the renal artery with a bulldog. The renal capsule will be resected using scissors under warm ischemia, which will take about 25 minutes.
Patient: How will you stop the bleeding?
Doctor: Hemostasis will be achieved using a combination of cautery, hemostatic agents, and suturing. We will use sutures preloaded with clips to secure a suture line, allowing for lateral compression perpendicular to the renal capsule.
Patient: What will the results be like?
Doctor: The histopathology report confirmed clear-cell renal carcinoma with negative surgical margins. According to the TNM 2017 classification, it's stage pT1a.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means that the cancer is in its early stage and we were able to remove it completely. We will continue to monitor your condition, but the prognosis is generally good for stage pT1a kidney cancer.

Doctor: Hi there, I understand you've been suffering from HCC with multiple lung metastases for the past 3 months. You're a hepatitis B carrier, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I see that you were admitted complaining of a headache. We performed a brain MRI scan to check for any brain metastasis. The results showed a solid mass occupying your left nasal cavity, measuring 3.7 × 1.8 × 2.8 cm.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Yes, the mass showed iso-signal intensity on the T1 weighted image, high signal intensity on the T2 weighted image, and heterogeneous well enhancement on the Gd-T1 weighted image. Gradient-echo images also showed small foci of low signal, suggesting haemorrhage in the mass.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: This means that there might be bleeding within the mass. We didn't find any restricted diffusion in the mass on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map. Metastasis of HCC was suggested, as your nasal cavity was normal on a positron emission tomography CT scan that had been performed 3 months ago.
Patient: I see. I have developed some symptoms like left nasal obstruction, clear rhinorrhea, and left facial pain.
Doctor: Those symptoms are consistent with the mass in your nasal cavity. We performed an excisional biopsy with a CT scan 17 days after the MRI scan. It showed that the mass had rapidly increased in size to 6.2 × 2.2 × 3.4 cm, with involvement of the ostium of the nasolacrimal duct and the lateral wall of the anterior nasal cavity.
Patient: Wow, that's a big change.
Doctor: Yes, it is. There was no calcification in the mass on the pre-contrast CT scan. We conducted a punch biopsy and the histological examination revealed tumor cells with enlarged nucleoli and clear cytoplasm arranged in trabecular cords and glandular arrays, consistent with metastatic HCC.
Patient: So, what's the grade of the tumor?
Doctor: The tumor is grade 2, which means it's moderately differentiated. We were planning for a resection of the tumor, but unfortunately, your general condition has declined.
Patient

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've got some redness in my right eye and I saw a worm moving in my left eye.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any exposure to rural streams during your childhood?
Patient: Yes, I used to play in them when I was a kid.
Doctor: Alright, let's perform an ocular examination to check your visual acuity and look for any other findings. 
*After examination*
Doctor: Your visual acuity is 6/5 in both eyes, which is normal. I found a temporal subconjunctival hemorrhage in your right eye, but the worm in your left eye is no longer present.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: I'll reassure you that this is not a major issue. However, if you see the worm again, please come back to the clinic.
Patient: Sure, thanks.
*Eleven months later*
Patient: Hi again, I saw the worm in my left eye and I've been experiencing recurrent redness and a feeling of something moving in that eye. I also have generalized body itching, which gets worse at night.
Doctor: Alright, let's examine your eye again.
*After examination*
Doctor: I found a mobile worm in the temporal subconjunctival area of your left eye, which soon migrated to the superior bulbar conjunctiva.
Patient: Oh no, what do we do?
Doctor: We will perform a conjunctival incision to extract the worm using forceps and repair the wound.
*After the procedure*
Doctor: The worm has been successfully removed. Histology confirmed it as an adult Loa loa. We've also done a blood work up, which showed negative results for microfilaria but positive eosinophilia at 44.4%.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that there's an elevated level of eosinophils in your blood, which can be associated with a parasitic infection. We will treat you with oral Albendazole to address this issue.
Patient: Alright, thanks for your help.

Doctor: Hello, I see from your history that you have osteoarthritis and hypothyroidism. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, doc. I noticed a rapidly growing lesion near my left eye about 3 weeks ago, and it's been growing ever since. My primary care physician referred me to you.
Doctor: I see. Let's take a look at the lesion. Upon examination, it appears to be a medial orbital mass causing ectropion of the lower eyelid and symptomatic epiphora. We should perform a CT scan of the orbits to further investigate this lesion.
Patient: Alright, doc. What did the CT scan results show?
Doctor: The CT scan showed a 2.0 × 1.6 × 1.0 cm nonenhancing intraorbital soft tissue lesion abutting the nasal lacrimal duct, lateral and inferior to the globe, without definite osseous remodeling. There is no thickening of the lateral rectus muscle or inflammation. There is a moderate lateral displacement of the intraocular structures, but the globe is intact.
Patient: Oh, I see. What's the next step, doc?
Doctor: We performed an anterior orbitotomy with biopsy 4 days after your presentation. The pathology was initially read as positive for intermediate grade epithelioid carcinoma, but after an outside consultation, the diagnosis was edited to epithelioid sarcoma with rhabdoid features (proximal type).
Patient: What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: Immunohistochemical stains revealed the tumor to be AE1/AE3 strong positive, GATA3 strong positive, vimentin strong positive, EMA focal positive, calponin focal positive, and a series of other markers were negative. This helps us better understand the nature of the tumor.
Patient: Considering my age and the tumor's histology, what are my treatment options?
Doctor: Due to your age and the tumor histology, chemotherapy is not recommended by medical oncology. We completed your staging workup with a soft tissue neck CT, which showed no evidence of abnormal lymph nodes. Additionally, a chest/abdomen/pelvis CT showed no evidence of metastatic disease in your chest, abdomen, or pelvis. Thus, the disease is localized to the left orbit only.
Patient: That's somewhat relieving. What's the plan moving

Immunohistochemical stains were positive for AE1/AE3, GATA3, vimentin, and focally positive for EMA and calponin. Staging workup with neck and chest/abdomen/pelvis CT scans showed no evidence of metastatic disease.

Doctor: Hi, I see that you were admitted after experiencing a sudden thunderclap headache, preceded by an acute loss of consciousness at your home. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. It happened so suddenly.
Doctor: I understand. Were there any past history of hypertension, seizures, drug abuse, trauma, or infection before this incident?
Patient: No, I never had any of those issues.
Doctor: Okay. On admission, our initial clinical examination showed you were unconscious with a GCS score of 10/15, which corresponds to Hunt & Hess classification Grade IV.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: After we stabilized you, we performed a CT scan, which showed diffuse subarachnoid haemorrhage and a cisternal clot at the interpeduncular cistern. This is classified as Modified Fisher I. We also noticed moderate dilatation of the temporal horns of the lateral ventricle.
Patient: What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: It means that you had bleeding in the space around your brain and a clot formed in a specific area. The dilatation of the temporal horns indicates some swelling in your brain. We then performed an angiography to further investigate the cause.
Patient: And what did the angiography show?
Doctor: The angiography revealed a ruptured saccular aneurysm of less than 3 mm in diameter, with a neck of 1.5 mm at the origin of your left frontopolar artery. Considering the small size of the aneurysm and its ruptured nature, we decided to manage it conservatively.
Patient: I see. But I heard that it bled again after 2 weeks?
Doctor: Yes, unfortunately, the aneurysm bled once more. We obtained another CT scan, which showed a superior interhemispheric frontal haematoma that had opened to your ventricular system. This was classified as Modified Fisher IV.
Patient: What did you do then?
Doctor: On Day 15 after the second haemorrhage, we performed a coiling procedure. After selectively placing a microcatheter in the left frontopolar artery aneurysm, we completely obliterated it with a single coil, maintaining the distal arterial lumen totally permeable.
Patient: Did the procedure work?
Doctor: Yes, it did.

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I ruptured my left Achilles tendon while playing soccer in June 2017 and had a tendon repair. But it re-ruptured after a month and an anastomosis procedure was done.
Doctor: I see. How did the anastomosis procedure go?
Patient: Unfortunately, it failed due to a local infection and skin necrosis.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. We can perform reconstructive surgery to address this issue. When did you first experience the initial injury?
Patient: It was 39 days ago.
Doctor: Alright. We've identified Staphylococcus aureus in your bacterial culture results, so we've been giving you a drip infusion of 1g of cefazolin twice a day after hospitalisation until 3 days after the surgery.
Patient: Okay, that's good to know.
Doctor: We've planned a simultaneous reconstruction of your tendon and soft tissue defects using an anterolateral thigh (ALT) and tensor fasciae latae (TFL) muscle chimeric flap, as well as Achilles tendon reconstruction using a TFL flap.
Patient: Hmm, I see.
Doctor: Surgical repair was performed 55 days after the primary rupture. We identified and marked the cutaneous perforator of the ALT flap on your skin preoperatively with a colour Doppler ultrasonography before the operation.
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: During the operation, we performed a wide debridement which resulted in a large combined Achilles tendon, 7 cm long, and overlying skin defect measuring 5.5 × 11 cm.
Patient: Oh, I didn't realize it was that big.
Doctor: Yes, it was quite significant. We elevated an ALT flap with a 6.5 × 13 cm skin island without fascia and a TFL musculofascial flap with an 11-cm length of iliotibial fascia from your right thigh.
Patient: Got it.
Doctor: In your case, the descending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery (LCFA), the pedicle of the ALT flap, branched directly from the deep femoral artery or common femoral artery. As a result, the vascular pedicles of the ALT and TFL flaps were independent of each other.

Doctor: Hi there, I'm Dr. Smith. I see you've been admitted to the Emergency Department due to agitation and an altered consciousness. Can you tell me when these symptoms started?
Patient: Hey, doctor. They started just a few hours ago, and I've been feeling a progressive loss of verbal contact.
Doctor: I understand. Your medical history shows that you have arterial hypertension, which is treated with atenolol. When you were admitted, your Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 9/15 with moderate neck stiffness. Your pupils were mid-size, reactive, and symmetric. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Your vital signs showed a body temperature of 36.6°C, arterial blood pressure of 180/95 mm Hg, heart rate of 120/min, and respiratory rate of 60/min. We performed a brain computed tomography (CT) without iodinated contrast agent perfusion before the lumbar puncture, and it didn't reveal any significant abnormalities. Due to your progressive respiratory distress, intubation was required. 
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also conducted a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, which showed a white blood cell (WBC) count of 560/¼l, with 99% granulocytes, proteins at 1264 mg/dl, glucose at 3 mg/dl, and lactate at 27 mmol/l.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: The CSF and blood cultures tested positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is sensitive to penicillin G and ceftriaxone. The minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) was 0.016 mcg/ml for penicillin G and ceftriaxone in the CSF, and 0.012 and 0.008 mcg/ml in blood for penicillin G and ceftriaxone, respectively.
Patient: So, what's the treatment plan?
Doctor: We've started you on a combination of dexamethasone (10 mg q6h for 4 days) and ceftriaxone (2 g q12h for 14 days). After 10 days, we'll repeat the CSF analysis to confirm the drop in WBC count and eradication of the causative microorganism.
Patient: Alright, thank you.

Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma back in 2013. I had a biopsy done after an endoscopic control examination. I was treated with radio adjuvant chemotherapy and surgery. I'm here for a follow-up appointment.

Doctor: That's great to hear. Let's discuss your recent check-up. In 2018, during your regular oncological follow-up, a subpleural pulmonary nodule was detected in the lower lobe of your left lung. It was 0.6 cm away from the surgical suture and 0.1 cm from the visceral pleura. The histologic examination demonstrated an epitheliomorphic neoplasm with acinar differentiation.

However, the tumor cells were negative for CK7 and Napsin A. A retrospective review of your previous primary tumor tissue showed similar histologic findings with TTF-1 positivity.
Patient: So, what's the diagnosis?
Doctor: Based on the positivity for CK20 and CDX2, and the negative results for CK7 and Napsin A, along with the morphology of the lesion, the diagnosis is metastasis from TTF1-positive primary colorectal adenocarcinoma.

MRI of the brain demonstrated restricted diffusion in the central aspect of the thalamus with surrounding vasogenic edema, indicative of acute venous infarction, and MR venography confirmed lack of flow-related signal in the deep venous system.

Doctor: Alright. Let's do a physical examination to check for any abnormalities. *examines patient* I see some mild paralysis in your right arm. Have you been experiencing any other symptoms, like palpitations or sweating?
Patient: Yes, I do feel palpitations and sweating sometimes.
Doctor: Alright. I'm not observing any exophthalmic or enlarged thyroid lobes. We'll need to conduct some tests to understand your condition better. We'll start with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA).
*After the tests*
Doctor: Your DWI results showed cortical and subcortical infarcts in the left MCA territory, but your MRA showed almost normal cerebral arteries with very mild stenosis of the left ICA. The vessel wall in the left ICA seems slightly thicker than the right, but the difference isn't very clear.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?

Additionally, we found autoantibodies related to Graves' Disease, such as anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (anti-TPO Ab, 148.0 IU/mL) and TSH receptor antibody (TRAb, 8.3 IU/mL).
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Other laboratory investigations showed leukopenia, anti-SS-A antibody (89.5 IU/mL), anti-SS-B antibody (12.4 IU/mL), and thrombin-antithrombin complex (TAT, 2.5 ng/mL). Your C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) were negative.
Patient: Is that something to be concerned about?

Doctor: Hello, I wanted to discuss the case of the two-year-old wild female cheetah from the temporary holding facility that developed seizures, raised tail, and arched back in November 2008. 
Patient's Family: Yes, we remember. She passed away despite the treatment. 
Doctor: That's correct. After her passing, she was submitted to the National Zoological Gardens of South Africa for a necropsy examination. She was part of a project to re-establish cheetah populations in protected, fenced reserves. The goal was to ensure the animals were fit and able to hunt effectively before being released.
Patient's Family: Yes, we know they went through a re-wilding process in a 1 ha enclosure initially.
Doctor: Exactly. While in the enclosure, antelope and birds were shot on the reserve as cheetah food. Once the cheetahs were able to open and feed off a full carcass, they were released from the enclosure and monitored intensively. The management, handling, and feeding schedules were consistent among the female and three males. Unfortunately, the female was the only mortality.
Patient's Family: That's so sad. What did the necropsy reveal?
Doctor: Due to delayed presentation, tissue preservation in the cheetah was poor. We examined a representative sample of all tissues except the eye and spinal cord. Both macroscopic and histological features were non-specific and non-diagnostic.
Patient's Family: Were there any other significant findings?
Doctor: Yes, we found four lead pellet fragments of less than one millimeter diameter in the cheetah's stomach. Tissue lead concentrations of 15.6 ppm and 17 ppm (wet weight) for kidney and liver respectively were determined at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute Toxicology Department using atomic absorption spectrophotometry. These findings were highly suggestive of lead poisoning.
Patient's Family: How did you confirm it was lead poisoning?
Doctor: Organ samples and blanks were acid digested and compared with standard lead solutions. The results confirmed the diagnosis of lead poisoning.
Patient's Family: Oh no, that's terrible. Thank you for letting us know and for conducting the examination.

Subjective: The patient, a two-year-old wild female cheetah, exhibited symptoms of seizures, a raised tail, and an arched back in November 2008. Assessment: The primary diagnosis for the cheetah was lead poisoning, based on the presence of lead pellets in the stomach and elevated lead levels in the kidney and liver tissues. Differential diagnoses were limited due to non-specific macroscopic and histological findings.
Plan: As the cheetah has passed away, the immediate plan includes reporting the findings to the relevant wildlife and conservation authorities to prevent similar cases. Recommendations

Doctor: Hello, it's nice to meet you. Can you please tell me about your medical history and any recent symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Hi, I am a 63-year-old female, a former smoker. I have hypothyroidism, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. Back in 2001, I had some generalized xanthomatous skin lesions.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Have you been experiencing any pain or discomfort lately?
Patient: Yes, I had abdominal pain back in 2004, and that's when my doctor suggested a computed tomography (CT) scan of my upper abdomen.
Doctor: I see. Did they use contrast for the CT scan?
Patient: Yes, they did.
Doctor: The CT scan with contrast demonstrated hypoattenuating tissue involving the abdominal aorta and its branches. This led to a discrete segmental narrowing of some vessels, characterized by narrowing of the aorta in the emergence region of the renal arteries and the left subclavian artery. Did they perform a tissue biopsy after the scan?
Patient: Yes, they took a biopsy, and it showed the presence of a pseudotumor.
Doctor: That biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of Erdheim-Chester Disease (ECD). Did they also perform an 18-FDG PET-CT scan to assess the extent of the disease?
Patient: Yes, they did.
Doctor: The FDG PET-CT showed signs of retroperitoneal fibrosis involving the abdominal aorta immediately above and at the emergence region of the renal arteries. There was also infiltrative tissue surrounding the aortic arch, descending aorta, and left common iliac artery. Did they check for any cardiac involvement?
Patient: They did a cardiac MRI, and it showed normal-sized chambers and preserved systolic function.
Doctor: That's good to hear. The cardiac MRI ruled out any cardiac involvement, which is a positive sign. It's essential to keep monitoring your condition and manage your hypothyroidism, hypertension, and dyslipidemia to prevent any complications. Make sure to follow up with your doctor regularly and report any new or worsening symptoms.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate the information and will continue to follow up with my doctor and manage my health.

Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What do we do now?
Doctor: We performed an open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture the following day. You were under general anesthesia and in the lateral position during the procedure. We approached your elbow posteriorly and used a 1.6-mm K-wire to hold the radial head in place. The olecranon was reduced under direct vision and held with a tension band using two 1.6-mm K-wires.
Patient: I see. So, what happened after the surgery?
Doctor: Postoperatively, we protected your elbow using an above-elbow slab for three weeks. After that, we started both active and passive range of motion exercises.
Patient: And how did my elbow heal after that?
Doctor: The fracture healed uneventfully, and within six weeks of fixation, you had a complete range of motion of 30-130 degrees at the elbow joint.
Patient: That's great to hear! Did anything else need to be done?
Doctor: Yes, we removed the implant after six months. You are now completely asymptomatic with a full range of flexion, extension, supination, and pronation, along with evidence of bony union.
Patient: Wow, thank you so much, Doctor! I'm so glad to be feeling better and back to normal.

Open reduction and internal fixation was performed under general anesthesia and in the lateral position with a 1.6-mm K-wire held in place by a tension band. The fracture healed uneventfully and provided a complete range of motion of 30-130 degrees within six weeks post-procedure, with no additional surgical intervention required postoperatively. At six months, postoperative recovery was asymptomatic with full range-of-motion and evidence of bony union, leading to the removal of an implant from the fracture. No further complications have been reported since the implant removal.

summarization.document:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having a fever and a headache for about a month now, and I've been vomiting too.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Let me ask you a few questions to better understand your situation. Have you been evaluated for immune-suppressed states like diabetes mellitus, AIDS, and hepatitis B and C virus infections?
Patient: Yes, I've been tested for all of those, and the results came back negative.
Doctor: Okay, that's good to know. Based on your symptoms of fever and headache, I'm considering a provisional diagnosis of meningoencephalitis. I'll order a CT brain scan with contrast to further investigate your condition.
Patient: Alright, thank you.
Doctor: The CT brain scan with contrast has shown multiple ring-enhancing lesions. We also performed an MRI brain spectroscopy, which revealed ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding oedema. These lesions are reported to be tuberculomas based on the imaging findings and MRI spectroscopy findings.
Patient: Oh! What does that mean?
Doctor: Tuberculomas are masses that can develop in the brain due to a tuberculosis infection. To further investigate, we performed a CT thorax scan with administration of intravenous contrast. The scan showed consolidation with cavitation in your left upper lobe and fibrosing mediastinitis. There was also soft tissue extension along the left hilum, narrowing the left pulmonary vessels and left bronchus. Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes were seen as well.
Patient: That sounds serious. What's the next step?
Doctor: Given the brain lesions and lung findings, we suspected tuberculosis. So, we performed a CT-guided biopsy of the thick-walled cavity. The histopathological and microbiological findings showed features of cryptococcus pneumonia.
Patient: What does that mean for my treatment?
Doctor: We've started you on antifungal therapy to treat the cryptococcus pneumonia. This should help you improve symptomatically.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything. I'm glad we found out what's causing my symptoms.
Doctor: You're welcome. It's important to closely monitor your progress during the antifungal therapy, and please keep in touch if you have any concerns or if your symptoms worsen. We're here to help.

Doctor: Hello, I understand you were hospitalized recently due to a motorcycle crash. Can you tell me about any symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yeah, I suffered some blunt chest and abdominal trauma, and I also had a concussion, but I didn't lose consciousness.
Doctor: I see. It's good to know that you were conscious. Your Glasgow Coma Scale score was 15, which means you were alert and responsive. You were also hemodynamically stable when you arrived at the hospital.
Patient: That's a relief to hear. How did my abdomen feel when I got here?
Doctor: Your abdomen was soft, nondistended, and nontender to palpation with no guarding. That's a good sign. We also conducted some lab tests to check your blood levels.
Patient: What were the results of the lab tests?
Doctor: Your labs were significant for a hemoglobin count of 14.2 g/dL, which is within the normal range of 13.517.5 g/dL. Your white blood count was 11.8 1000/¼L, slightly higher than the normal range of 4.511 1000/¼L, and your lactate level was 1.7 mmol/L, which is also within the normal range of 0.72.1 mmol/L. These levels remained stable throughout your hospital course.
Patient: Okay, so what happened next?
Doctor: We performed an initial intravenous contrast-enhanced CT scan of your abdomen and pelvis 10 minutes after you arrived. The CT scan was interpreted by a radiology resident 15 minutes later, and a board-certified emergency radiologist completed the final interpretation in an additional 1 hour and 25 minutes.
Patient: What did the CT scan show?
Doctor: The initial CT interpretation indicated nonspecific wall thickening of the proximal jejunum, and occult small bowel injury could not be excluded. Given these findings, we ordered a repeat CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast as per our institution's standard protocol for evaluation of possible occult bowel injury in blunt abdominal trauma.
Patient: When was the follow-up CT performed?
Doctor: The follow-up CT was performed after midnight, 8 hours after the initial CT. It demonstrated trace pneumoperitoneum, possibly originating from the splenic flexure of the colon without evidence of extravasation of oral contrast.

Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 12-year-old boy. Can you tell me what symptoms you've been experiencing recently?
Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling general malaise, drowsiness, appetite loss, nausea, and discomfort in my abdomen. My urine has also been darker than usual for the past two days.
Doctor: I understand. It seems you were admitted to the Clinic of Infectious Diseases at St. George University Hospital in Bulgaria. When you arrived, did they notice any changes in your skin or eyes?
Patient: Yes, they said my skin and conjunctivas were mildly jaundiced.
Doctor: Okay. On admission, were you able to walk and move around normally?
Patient: Yeah, I was ambulatory, and they didn't find any neurological symptoms at first.
Doctor: I see. Did your jaundice worsen, or did you experience any other symptoms after being admitted?
Patient: Yes, the jaundice got worse, and my malaise progressed. I also had abdominal pain, headache, and pain in the muscles of my lower extremities.
Doctor: Were you running a fever, or were you conscious during this time?
Patient: No, I was afebrile and conscious.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. It seems that between the 2nd and 14th day after admission, a neurological examination revealed some issues. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Sure. They found absent Achilles and knee-jerk reflexes, diminished brachioradialis reflex, and absent abdominal and cremasteric reflexes. They also said I had moderately decreased muscle power in my upper extremities and more pronounced power loss in my lower extremities.
Doctor: Did this affect your mobility, like sitting, standing, or moving around independently?
Patient: Yes, I had decreased mobility when lying in bed and was unable to sit, stand, or mobilize independently.
Doctor: How about your sensation? Did you have any changes in your sense of touch?
Patient: They said my deep sensation was preserved, but I had paresthesia in my palms and soles.
Doctor: Did you develop any facial issues, such as facial palsy?
Patient: Yes, I developed facial palsy, House-Brackmann grade V. It was more pronounced on the right side, and Bell's sign was positive

Doctor: Hi there, I understand your 1-year old mixed-breed dog has been referred to me due to an issue with her left eye. Can you please tell me more about the problem?
Patient: Yes, she's been having this mucopurulent discharge from her left eye for about 14 days now. It started suddenly after we took her for a walk in a meadow.
Doctor: I see. Did you notice any changes in her eye before the discharge started?
Patient: No, it was pretty much acute in onset and developed after that walk.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Has your dog received any treatment for this issue so far?
Patient: Yes, our previous veterinarian prescribed 0.3% tobramycin eye drops for her.
Doctor: How long has she been using the eye drops, and have you noticed any improvement since starting the therapy?
Patient: She's been using the drops for some days now, but we haven't seen any ocular improvement during this therapy.
Doctor: I understand. Let me perform an ophthalmic examination to get a better understanding of her condition. [After examination] I found an abundant mucopurulent to haemorrhagic discharge and a moderate conjunctival hyperemia in her left eye. I didn't see any other abnormalities in this eye. Her right eye appears to be normal.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: Based on the findings, the presumptive diagnosis is that your dog has unilateral dacryocystitis, which is an inflammation of the tear sac, likely due to a foreign body in her left eye.
Patient: Oh, I see. What can we do to help her?
Doctor: We will need to remove the foreign body and provide appropriate treatment to resolve the inflammation and infection. I will discuss the options with you and provide recommendations for follow-up care.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. We really appreciate your help with our dog's eye problem.

No ocular improvement has been observed despite the use of 0.3% tobramycin eye drops prescribed by a previous veterinarian.

Both the right and left eyelids are normal. A biopsy was performed to confirm the diagnosis of unilateral dacryocystitis, indicated by the presence of a foreign body in each eye. 
Assessment: Primary diagnosis is unilateral uveal dachshund-type dilation syndrome (UDDS), likely secondary to the occurrence of bilateral udder tear sac inflammation. Doctor: Hello, I see that you were admitted to our hospital with the chief complaint of jaundice in your skin and sclera, along with epigastric pain for the past two weeks. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. The yellowing and pain have been bothering me a lot.
Doctor: I understand. We've conducted several examinations to determine the cause, including enhanced abdominal and pelvic CT scans, a chest X-ray, an abdominal ultrasound, tumor markers, liver and renal function tests, and coagulation function tests. Let me go over the results with you.
Patient: Okay, please do.
Doctor: The CT scans revealed a low-density mass of 4.0 cm in diameter located in the uncinate process of your pancreas. Additionally, your intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts are obviously dilated, and your pancreatic duct is slightly dilated as well. Doctor: Hello! I see you have a history of age-related macular degeneration. What brings you to the clinic today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was told to come in for a routine dilated fundus exam.
Doctor: Alright, let's start by checking your visual acuity. Your Snellen visual acuity is 20/100 OD in your right eye and count fingers OS in your left eye. I'll now perform the exam.
Patient: Okay, Doctor.
Doctor: I'm noticing some concerning findings. There is end-stage AMD in your left eye and subretinal hemorrhage in your right eye. I think we should refer you for an ocular ultrasound.
Patient: Hmm, alright.
*After the ocular ultrasound*
Doctor: The results show that you have subretinal hemorrhage in your right eye, secondary to progression of your macular degeneration. We will initiate Anti-VEGF treatment and continue it for several months.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
*After several months*
Doctor: Your recent tests show a choroidal lesion measuring 14.5 × 14.6 mm in basal dimension with a thickness of 6.4 mm. There is low to medium reflectivity, moderate irregularity, and trace spontaneous vascularity. These findings are consistent with a clinical diagnosis of choroidal melanoma.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We need to do a liver ultrasound to check for any lesions and further evaluate your condition.
*After liver ultrasound*
Doctor: The liver ultrasound showed questionable focal lesions, so we'll need a CT scan of your abdomen and pelvis for further evaluation.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I am a 26-year-old primigravida and I am 23 weeks pregnant. I have a distension in my abdomen that's worrying me.

Patient: Yes, two years ago, I had a left salpingo-oopherectomy for an ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma. I received six cycles of combined chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel afterward and was advised to use contraception. I didn't follow up after that, and now I am pregnant.
Doctor: Thank you for providing that information. Let's do an abdomen examination to check for any issues. *After examining the patient* It appears that there is some ascites and your uterus is about the size of a 24 weeks pregnancy with palpable fetal parts. We should also do an ultrasound examination to investigate further.
Patient: Okay, what did you find in the ultrasound?
Doctor: The ultrasound shows an intra-uterine pregnancy of 23 weeks and a right ovarian mass of 12.8 x 8.8 cm with solid and cystic areas containing free fluid with internal echoes. Your CA-125 level is also elevated at 80 IU/ml. Based on these findings, it seems like you have recurrent ovarian cancer during your pregnancy.
Patient: Oh no, what are my options?
Doctor: Ideally, we would recommend surgical management to address the cancer. However, I understand that you declined this option. Instead, we started you on two courses of chemotherapy with a single dose of carboplatin 450mg intravenously at three-week intervals.
Patient: Yes, I remember that. But I couldn't do the third course because my liver function tests were not good.
Doctor: That's correct. Unfortunately, the ascites has been progressive, which has led to maternal respiratory distress and fetal growth restriction and oligohydroamnios. We have decided to plan an elective Cesarean section with staging laparotomy at 34 weeks for the breech presentation with decreased liquor and gross ascites, after completion of steroid cover.
Patient: What will happen during the surgery?
Doctor: Intraoperatively, we will drain the hemorrhagic ascetic fluid, which could be around 20 liters. We will also examine the omentum, which appears to be agglutinated over the intestine

Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to the Department of Neurosurgery today. What brings you in?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having this left facial droop and some spasms on the same side.
Doctor: I see. Other than the facial droop and spasm, do you have any relevant past medical or surgical history?
Patient: No, I don't have any other medical or surgical history.
Doctor: Alright. Based on your symptoms and our examination, it appears you have an unruptured right middle cerebral artery (MCA) aneurysm. We will need to admit you to the hospital for a right-sided craniotomy to clip the aneurysm.
Patient: Oh, okay. What does that procedure involve?
Doctor: The procedure is called a pterional craniotomy, and it will be performed under general anesthesia. During the surgery, we will use intraoperative neurophysiological monitoring methods to ensure your safety.
Patient: What does that monitoring involve?
Doctor: We will use median, ulnar, and posterior tibial nerve somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) in a standard fashion. These methods help us monitor the function of your motor pathways during the surgery. Transcranial motor evoked potential (TCMEP) and direct cortical motor evoked potential (DCMEP) will also be used.
Patient: I see. And what about the stimulation?
Doctor: For TCMEP, we will use a multi-pulse train of six with a pulse width of 50 µsec and an interstimulus interval (ISI) of 2 ms (500 Hz). The voltage stimulation will be between 100 and 300 volts, controlling for the inhibition of the "crossover" response. For DCMEP, the stimulation parameters include a multi-pulse train of five delivered at a constant current of 15 mA with a pulse width of 500 µsec and an ISI of 2 ms (500 Hz).
Patient: Okay, that's a lot of information. What about the monitoring sites?
Doctor: We will use upper and lower extremity muscles as target acquisition sites. Standard intraoperative electromyography (EMG) needle electrodes will be used for TCMEP and DCMEP during the surgery.
Patient: Got it. When do you collect the TCMEP data?
Doctor: TCMEP

Doctor: Hi there, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having this really bad headache for the past three days. The pain is sharp and constant, and I would say it's about an 8 out of 10 in severity.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history? Do you have any pre-existing conditions?
Patient: Yes, I have hyperlipidemia and I usually suffer from one or two migraines per month.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. Have you experienced any other symptoms along with the headache, like nausea or vomiting?
Patient: Yes, actually. I've been feeling nauseous and I've vomited three times.
Doctor: I understand. What medications have you taken recently to try to alleviate the pain?
Patient: I took sumatriptan, acetaminophen, and ibuprofen within the past 48 hours, but they didn't help much.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Let me examine your head. *Examines patient* I noticed some mild bilateral occipital tenderness to palpation, but no neurological deficits or midline tenderness. I recommend we try some additional medications in the ED triage. We'll start with metoclopramide 10 mg and ketorolac 15 mg intravenously. 
Patient: Okay, I hope that helps.
*60 minutes later*
Doctor: How are you feeling now? Has the pain improved after receiving the medications?
Patient: It's a little better, but I still have a lot of head pain. I'd say it's about a 7 out of 10 in severity now.
Doctor: I see. Let's try a different approach. We're going to administer bilateral GON blocks with a total of one mL of 1% lidocaine to each site. 
Patient: Alright, if you think that will help.
*15 minutes after the procedure*
Doctor: How is your pain now, after the GON blocks?
Patient: It's much better, thank you. I'd say it's about a 3 out of 10 now.
Doctor: Great, let's continue to monitor your pain. 
*1.5 hours post-procedure*
Doctor: How are you feeling now? Is the pain still at a 3 out of 10?
Patient: Yes, it's still at a 3.

Doctor: Have you had any neurological symptoms such as headaches during this pregnancy?
Patient: No, I haven't had any headaches during this pregnancy.
Doctor: Do you have any history of gestational hypertension or any family history of chronic hypertension, diabetes, or chronic kidney diseases?

Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 31-year-old female patient with symptomatic postpartum deep venous thrombosis in your right leg. Can you describe the symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yeah, my right leg has been really swollen and painful. It's been difficult to walk around.
Doctor: I understand. So, before your surgical thrombectomy, you received a suprarenal IVC filter due to the short distance between the thrombus in the distal IVC and the inflow of renal veins. The surgical access was established via venotomy of the common femoral vein, and an occlusion balloon was used for the thrombectomy. How did you feel after the procedure?
Patient: I felt a bit better, but still had some pain and swelling in my leg.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. In a follow-up CT, we found that the filter had dislodged and tilted towards the right IVC wall with its legs piercing the contralateral wall and extending into the left renal vein. This was likely due to the surgical thrombectomy. You were given oral anticoagulation with Warfarin, but unfortunately, there was a re-thrombosis. We then performed catheter-directed thrombolysis, including stenting of the common iliac veins and the IVC. However, we didn't attempt filter retrieval at that time due to the large amount of clot within the filter.
Patient: Oh, I see. So, what happened next?
Doctor: After 5 weeks of Warfarin therapy, you were scheduled for a retrieval, which was considered mandatory due to the displaced and tilted filter with penetrating legs. We introduced a 14-F sheath, an SOS catheter, a Bentson wire, and an EN Snare to create a loop. We attempted the single loop-snare technique several times, but it kept slipping around the filter legs.
Patient: That sounds difficult. What did you do then?
Doctor: To stabilize the loop, we formed a second loop using the same technique around the filter tip. With two loops around the filter tip, we were finally able to successfully pull the filter away from the wall and into the 14F sheath.
Patient: That's a relief! What's the next step now?

Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 55-year-old African American male with a significant past medical history of breast cancer. What brings you in today?
Patient: I recently had a surveillance computed tomography (CT) scan of my chest, abdomen, and pelvis, and they found something.
Doctor: Yes, I see here that the CT scan showed incidental acute appendicitis. Were you experiencing any symptoms when you came in for the scan?
Patient: No, I was asymptomatic during the scan, but in the following days, I developed nausea and vomiting along with right lower quadrant abdominal pain.
Doctor: That's consistent with appendicitis. We'll have to admit you to the general surgery service for treatment. I also noticed from your chart that you have an extensive history with cancer, is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, it all started in 2014 when I had a resection of an enlarging, ulcerating chest mass on the right side.
Doctor: I see that the pathology report from the wide local excision of the mass demonstrated estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, and HER2/neu-negative metastatic adenocarcinoma. Patient: Yes, that's right. My oncology team has been closely monitoring me, and I've been treated with tamoxifen for hormone therapy.
Doctor: I also noticed that in May of 2017, due to an enlarged anterior mediastinal wall lymph node discovered on CT surveillance, you underwent a CT-guided biopsy and positron emission tomography (PET). The biopsy was negative for malignancy, but the PET showed abnormal hypermetabolic activity within a retrosternal nodule, intense activity in a mixed focus in the manubrium, and several hypermetabolic nodes within the mediastinum. It also showed an abnormal hypermetabolic focus in the cecum, which was suspicious for a colon primary. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, they tried to do a colonoscopy, but the gastroenterologist couldn't advance the colonoscope past the transverse colon due to technical reasons.
Doctor: I see. Medical oncology decided to continue with close surveillance.

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I am a 75-year-old woman, and I've been having a loss of appetite for a week now. I'm 132 cm tall and weigh 34 kg.
Doctor: I see. Are you taking any medications currently?
Patient: Yes, I take aspirin, celecoxib, and amlodipine for angina and hypertension.
Doctor: Alright. I will need to run some laboratory examinations to better understand your condition. 
*After the examinations*
Doctor: Your lab results show that your Hb has decreased modestly to 10.7 g/dl. I would like to monitor your condition and ask that you return in two weeks for a follow-up.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
*Two weeks later*
Patient: Doctor, my anorexia has worsened day by day, and I decided to admit myself to the hospital.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. On admission day 1, you were alert and fully oriented. Your blood pressure and pulse rate were stable. However, your laboratory examinations showed that your Hb and hematocrit levels decreased remarkably to 4.8 g/dl and 15%, respectively. Your white blood count and C-reactive protein (CRP) increased slightly to 9900 /mm3 and 4.64 mg/dl, respectively. Additionally, your albumin level decreased to 2.5 g/dl and your creatine level increased slightly to 1.14 mg/dl, with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 41.7 ml/min. We also conducted chest and abdominal computed tomography (CT), but it didn't detect any abnormal lesions.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: On admission day 2, you vomited large amounts of bright red blood, and your Hb level further decreased to 2.9 g/dl. We performed an urgent transfusion of 560 ml of red blood cells. An endoscopic examination detected active bleeding from a gastric ulcer, so we performed endoscopic clipping on the bleeding lesion.
Patient: I'm glad you found the issue. Did my Hb levels improve after that?
Doctor: Yes, your Hb improved to 8.9 g/dl. However, you did not respond to verbal or pain stimuli despite your eyes having opened. You showed normal light reflexes without

Doctor: Hello, can you tell me why you were admitted to the hospital back in June 2016?
Patient: Yeah, I was admitted because of weakness in my right arm and problems with my speech, like slurring.
Doctor: I see. You were diagnosed with cerebral infarction in the left middle cerebral artery area and deep vein thrombosis. Your ECG demonstrated normal sinus rhythm and echocardiography revealed no intra-cardiac thrombus or vegetation. You were then discharged with a prescription for apixaban. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: In August 2016, you were readmitted to the hospital due to recurrent right arm weakness and slurred speech. The MRI showed multiple cerebral infarctions in both cerebral hemispheres and the cerebellum. At this point, Trousseau's syndrome was suspected. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: So, your apixaban was stopped and you were given an intravenous drip of heparin instead. Echocardiography revealed mild mitral regurgitation with vegetation on the mitral valve. Although your lab results showed no evidence of infection, you were given ceftriaxone and gentamicin as a precaution against infective endocarditis. You were then referred to our hospital for surgery. 
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: A CT scan revealed a left renal infarction and multiple swollen lymph nodes around both the abdominal aorta and stomach with antral hypertrophy. This suggested advanced gastric cancer or lymphoma. Despite the heparin and antibiotics therapy, the vegetation on your mitral valve didn't change. So, cardiac surgery was performed on day 5 after your referral. 
Patient: Okay, and what happened during the surgery?
Doctor: During the surgery, extracorporeal circulation was instituted employing aortic and bicaval cannulation. After aortic cross-clamping, the mitral valve was exposed via a left atriotomy. Both mitral leaflets had vegetation on the surface, and a major vegetation 15 mm in width was evident on the anterior leaflet. These were resected in their entirety and replaced with a 25-mm Epic bioprosthesis.
Patient: Hmm, I see.
Doctor: Continuous intravenous heparin administration was resumed the following day, aiming for an

Doctor: Hi there, I heard you've been experiencing some wrist pain and unsightly appearance of your wrist after a previous fracture. Can you please describe how it feels and when these symptoms started to develop?
Patient: Yeah, the pain is mostly on the ulnar side of my wrist, and it started about a year after the fracture. The appearance of my wrist seems a bit deformed too.
Doctor: I see. Based on the physical examination and the tests we ran, it appears that you have a growth plate fracture in your right distal radius, specifically a SalterHarris type II fracture. You were initially treated with cast immobilization and closed reduction, which allowed the fracture to heal. However, the wrist pain and deformity you're experiencing now are due to a condition called partial physeal arrest.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean?
Doctor: Partial physeal arrest occurs when the growth plate in your wrist is damaged, causing it to stop growing properly. In your case, radiographs showed a shortening deformity of the distal radius and an abnormal radial inclination of the articular surface. A CT scan was also performed to evaluate the deformity and for preoperative simulation with a low-radiation setting.
Patient: So, what's the plan to fix this?
Doctor: We have planned a two-stage operation for you. The first stage will involve a procedure called distraction osteogenesis to gradually lengthen the affected bone. The second stage will be the Langenskiöld procedure, which aims to remove the physeal bar and reestablish physeal growth.
Patient: Will this help with the pain and appearance of my wrist?
Doctor: Yes, the goal of the operation is to correct the deformities of the wrist and improve its appearance and function. In the first operation, we'll use a closed-wedge osteotomy to correct the distal radius, and an external fixator called the Orthofix MiniRail Fixator

to lengthen the affected bone, followed by a Langenskiöld procedure in the second stage to remove the physeal bar and attempt to reestablish growth. Preoperative preparation includes obtaining informed consent and adhering to ethical guidelines

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some issues lately. I work at a shrimp farm in Yingkou, and I had watery diarrhea on August 24th.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms and any relevant history?
Patient: Well, I had a single episode of watery diarrhea, dizziness, and vomiting after consuming raw mollusc from the sediment in Yingkou. I don't have any immune-compromising diseases, and I don't abuse alcohol.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. How did you manage your symptoms after the episode?
Patient: I took ciprofloxacin for two days, and the watery diarrhea disappeared after three days of antibiotic treatment.
Doctor: Okay, it seems that the antibiotic helped. Did you have any laboratory tests done?
Patient: Yes, I had some biochemical tests and my white blood cell count was high, 14 × 109/L. They also did a stool culture.
Doctor: Were there any findings from the stool culture?
Patient: The stool culture was spread onto Thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose and MacConkey agar plates, and it showed suspected positive results for V. cholerae.
Doctor: I see. Were there any further tests done to confirm the presence of V. cholerae?
Patient: Yes, they obtained a pure culture and identified the bacterium as V. cholerae through the VITEK-2 bacterial identifier system and sequencing of the 16S rDNA genes.
Doctor: Did they perform any tests to determine the specific strain of V. cholerae?
Patient: They did an agglutination test with O1 and O139 antisera, and it showed that the strain was a non-O1/O139 V. cholerae.
Doctor: Alright. Were there any tests conducted to assess the virulence factors of the V. cholerae strain?
Patient: Yes, they did a PCR test for outer membrane protein, TCP expression, haemagglutinin, protease, and central regulatory protein, among others.
Doctor: What were the results of the PCR tests?
Patient: The results showed that the strain was only positive for the outer membrane protein, TCP expression, haemagglut

Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your medical history?
Patient: Oh, I don't have any remarkable medical history. I've been pretty healthy overall.
Doctor: I understand you were admitted to another hospital due to fever, fatigue, and anorexia. What treatments were provided there?
Patient: They gave me acetaminophen and antibiotics, but my condition kept getting worse. I even started having vomiting and myalgia, which made it hard to move.
Doctor: I see, so you were transferred to our hospital 7 days after your initial admission. Upon admission, we found that your liver enzyme and creatine phosphokinase levels were high. Have you ever experienced jaundice, pruritus, clay stools, melena, hematemesis, abdominal distension, or altered sensorium?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those issues.
Doctor: What about your lifestyle habits? Have you consumed alcohol or experienced any toxic exposure?
Patient: I've only had a small amount of ethanol occasionally, and I haven't been exposed to any toxins that I'm aware of.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Have you ever had any major surgeries, blood transfusions, or intravenously injected drug use prior to the onset of the disease?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: Do you have a history of any chronic diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, tuberculosis, thyroid disease, or blood disorders?
Patient: No, I don't have any of those conditions.
Doctor: Okay, let's discuss your current condition. Upon admission, your vital signs were as follows: body temperature, 37.2 °C; blood pressure, 110/72 mmHg; pulse, 75 beats/min; respiratory rate, 20 breaths/min; and oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Our physical examination showed mild enlargement of your liver, no pitting edema in both legs, and no coarse crackles over the lung fields. The laboratory findings are presented in the table, which we'll discuss shortly.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: Additionally, a chest radiography showed absence of pulmonary congestion, pleural effusion, and cardiomegaly. Electrocardiography was not performed on admission. Computed tomography of the chest and abdomen revealed minimal pericardial effusion, diffuse swelling, and an internal heterogeneous image in the liver.

Doctor: Good morning, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was diagnosed with left temporal glial neoplasia in May 2014 after I had a seizure.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms and the tests you had done?
Patient: Well, I had an MRI which showed an infiltrative lesion with poorly defined contours in my left temporal lobe. It also showed an increase in the left temporal gyrus cortex.
Doctor: Hmm, it seems like the lesion compromised a large part of your temporal lobe and extended to the temporal isthmus, the posterior aspect of the insula, and was deep in the trigeminal effigy of the left lateral ventricle. There was also diffuse erasure of the regional cortical sulci and the Sylvian fissure, with slight compression over the atrium of the left lateral ventricle. Did you have a biopsy done to confirm the diagnosis?
Patient: Yes, I had a stereotactic biopsy in April 2014, and it indicated oligodendroglioma grade II.
Doctor: Okay, and how has your treatment been going since then?
Patient: I received TMZ with cycles every 23 days from September 2014 to July 2015. But in 2016, there was tumor growth, so I had an MRI in February.
Doctor: What did the MRI show about the evolution of the tumor?
Patient: The MRI showed an increase in the dimensions of the remaining lesion, especially in the temporal isthmus, which had a similar expansive effect on the adjacent encephalic structures.
Doctor: I understand. And what was the next step in your treatment?
Patient: I underwent a partial surgical resection followed by chemoradiation and lasting 6 cycles of PCV associated with CBD. The CBD dosage ranged from 100 to 200 mg/day.
Doctor: How was your overall health and well-being during the chemoradiation?
Patient: I had an excellent clinical performance, practiced sports, and only had a few symptoms of fatigue and nausea.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Did you have an MRI control after the chemoradiation to assess the results?
Patient: Yes, the MRI control was used to characterize post-operative changes and showed a significant reduction of the infiltrative components of the tumor.
Doctor: That's promising. What was the result of the

A biopsy confirmed oligodendroglioma grade II in April 2014. document.summarization:
Subjective: The patient, diagnosed with left temporal glial neoplasia (oligodendroglioma grade II initially, later progressed to grade III) in May 2014, reports a history of seizures, tumor growth, and treatments including TMZ chemotherapy, partial surgical resection, chemoradiation, and PCV with CBD. Symptoms experienced include fatigue and nausea, but overall well-being has been good with active participation in sports.
Objective: Initial MRI revealed an infiltrative lesion in the left temporal lobe with poorly defined contours and increased cortex in the left temporal gyrus. Subsequent MRIs showed progression and post-treatment reduction of the tumor. Biopsy confirmed oligodendroglioma grade II, which later progressed to grade III based on increased Ki67 staining of 9%. The patient's clinical performance has been excellent despite the diagnosis and treatments.
Assessment: The primary diagnosis is oligodendroglioma, currently grade III, with a history of progression from grade II. Differential diagnoses were likely considered and ruled out through biopsy and imaging. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the significant reduction in tumor size post-treatment, though the progression to a higher grade indicates a potentially more aggressive disease course.

Doctor: Hello, I see that you were referred to our department in June 2011 by a head and neck surgeon to improve your upper denture retention and stability. Can you tell me a bit about your medical history?
Patient: Sure, doc. I was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the maxillary gingiva in May 2005. I had to undergo a bunch of surgeries like extended left maxillectomy, anterior and middle cranial base resection, left ophthalmectomy, and flap reconstruction using the rectus abdominis muscle.
Doctor: I see. During your physical examination, I noticed a recessed deformation on the left side of your face due to the left ophthalmectomy. The function of your left levator palpebrae muscle has been eliminated to a slight elevation using the frontal muscle. There's also a metal plate anchored to the inferior wall of your orbit. How have you been managing with these changes?
Patient: It's been tough, but I'm getting used to it.
Doctor: I also observed that during the mesh titanium plate reconstruction, your left ethmoid bone, inferior nasal turbinate, maxilla, alisphenoid, medial and lateral pterygoid muscle were excised. Intraorally, your left maxilla has been excised from the midline and the rectus abdominis muscle flap was sutured directly to your soft palate. The peripheral mucous membrane around your left upper lip is scarred, without the oral vestibule. Have you experienced any discomfort or difficulty with this?
Patient: Yes, sometimes it's uncomfortable and the flap margin has moved along with the surrounding soft tissue.
Doctor: I see that the 70 × 50 mm flap is sagging from its weight and is in contact with your mandibular molars, which reduces the volume of your oral cavity unless you wear dentures. Your maxilla has been removed from the midline to the maxillary tuberosity, while your mandible has been removed from the anterior border of the ramus to the coronoid process. Has this caused any issues with your dentures?
Patient: Yeah, it's been a bit difficult to adjust to them.
Doctor: During the reconstruction, the dead space was eliminated by placing the abdominal rectus muscle from the anterior cranial base to the oral cavity (Fig.). Have you noticed any expiratory leakage or food reflux?
Patient: No, I haven't

He experiences discomfort due to flap sagging and contact with the mandibular molars, which reduces oral cavity volume. No issues with expiratory leakage or food reflux have been reported.
Objective : Physical examination revealed a recessed deformation on the left side, elimination of left levator palpebrae muscle by the frontal muscle. The left ethmoid bone, inferior nasal turbinate, maxilla, alisphenoid, medial and lateral pterygoid muscle were excised and sutured to the soft palate, with scarred peripheral mucous membranes and an oral vestibule missing. A 70 × 50 mm flap flap with a diameter of 40 mm was placed to improve flap stability and reduce flap-related discomfort.

Subjective: The patient, referred by a head and neck surgeon, reports difficulties with upper denture retention and stability following extensive surgeries for squamous cell carcinoma of the maxillary gingiva diagnosed in May 2005. Surgeries included extended left maxillectomy, anterior and middle cranial base resection, left ophthalmectomy, and flap reconstruction using the rectus abdominis muscle. The patient experiences discomfort and has noticed movement in the flap margin and surrounding soft tissue. The patient confirms adherence to follow-up appointments and has not experienced tumor recurrence, metastasis, expiratory leakage, or food reflux.
Objective: Physical examination reveals a recessed deformation on the left side of the face, absence of the left levator palpebrae muscle function, and presence of a metal plate in the inferior orbital wall. Doctor: Hello there, I see you've brought your 7-year-old son in today. What seems to be the problem?
Parent: Hi, Doctor. We're from Miandoab. He suddenly started experiencing febrile serial generalized tonic-clonic seizures and was hospitalized in Shahid Abbasi teaching Hospital.
Doctor: I see. Has he had any history of prenatal or postnatal diseases?
Parent: No, he has had a normal growth and just completed the first grade of primary school. His mother and I are cousins, but we are both healthy.
Doctor: Okay. So, after controlling his seizures with bolus doses of phenobarbital and phenytoin, did his condition improve?
Parent: Unfortunately, his consciousness level decreased, and he needed endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation. Then he was transferred to the tertiary subspecialty ward in Urmias Motahari Hospital.
Doctor: I understand. When I first examined him, he was in a deep coma, but his vital signs were normal. Upon further physical examination, I noticed his pupils were dilated with an inadequate response to light, his liver was palpable about 4 cm below the costal margin, his muscular tone was severely diminished, and deep tendon reflexes were undetectable. His examination was otherwise normal.
Parent: What do the laboratory tests say about his condition?
Doctor: The routine laboratory tests revealed a nonketotic hypoglycemia and elevated liver enzymes. We consulted with an endocrinologist and took blood and urine samples for further evaluation into the exact cause of his hypoglycemia.
Parent: What did those tests reveal?
Doctor: The tests ruled out several possible causes including lipid malabsorption (TG=92 mg/dl, cholesterol 73 mg/dl, LDL=37 mg/dl), disorders of the respiratory chain (lactate=13 ng/dl), adrenal insufficiency (cortisol=62.4µg/dl), hypopituitarism (ACTH=411 pg/ml), and hyper insulinemia (insulin=0.7µIU/ml).
Parent: Did you find any viral or immune cause for his hepatitis?
Doctor: Our pediatric gastroenterologist suggested additional laboratory tests to detect any viral or immune cause of hepatitis, but unfortunately, those tests revealed nothing. The urine toxicology screening test was also negative.
Parent
document.prediction: Subjective: The patient, a 7-year-old male from Miandoab, presented with sudden onset of febrile serial generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He has no history of prenatal or postnatal diseases, normal growth, and just completed the first grade of primary school. His mother and aunt are both healthy. Initially, his seizures were controlled with phenobarbital and phenytoin, but his condition deteriorated, requiring endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation. Subsequently, he was transferred to the tertiary subspecialty ward of Urmia's Motahari Hospital, where he developed a deep coma and was found to be in nonketotic hypoglycemia with elevated liver enzymes. No viral or immune causes of hepatitis were identified in the urine toxicology screening test, though additional tests suggested a possible viral origin but were ruled out by negative results for viral, immune, or infectious factors.
document.summarization:
Subjective: The patient, a 7-year-old boy, presented with sudden onset of febrile serial generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He was initially treated with bolus doses of phenobarbital and phenytoin but subsequently experienced a decreased level of consciousness, requiring endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation. The patient's parents are first cousins; however, there is no reported history of prenatal or postnatal diseases. The patient had normal growth and development until this event.
Objective: On examination, the patient was in a deep coma with normal vital signs. Physical findings included dilated pupils with poor light response, liver palpable 4 cm below the costal margin, severely diminished muscular tone, and absent deep tendon reflexes. Laboratory tests showed nonketotic hypoglycemia and elevated liver enzymes. Further testing ruled out lipid malabsorption, disorders of the respiratory chain, adrenal insufficiency, hypopituitarism, and hyperinsulinemia. Viral and immune causes of hepatitis were also ruled out through additional laboratory tests. Urine toxicology was negative.
Assessment: The primary diagnosis is a severe neurological condition with hepatic involvement, characterized by nonketotic hypoglyce

Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about the injuries you sustained?
Patient: Hi, I had an electrical burn from a power line. It was pretty bad.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. It looks like you had 32% total body surface area third-degree injuries. Can you tell me more about the injury to your left knee?
Patient: Yeah, my left knee got an open joint injury. It was treated with three skin grafting procedures before something else was placed.
Doctor: That's right. The SEF, or spatial external fixator, was placed 24 days after your injury to help stabilize your knee. It was kept on for 8.5 weeks. We used Shantz pins and bars as the external fixator, and it was locked in full extension. 
Patient: Oh, I see. So, what happened after the SEF was placed?
Doctor: After the SEF placement, you required two additional skin grafting procedures on your left knee. You also had a bony prominence resection while in SEF. This means we removed a protruding piece of bone to help with your recovery.
Patient: I didn't know that. Were there any complications during my treatment?
Doctor: No significant complications were recorded during your treatment, which is good news. However, I noticed that there were no PT/OT notes or follow-up recorded. 
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: PT/OT refers to physical therapy and occupational therapy. It's important to have these sessions and follow-ups to ensure proper recovery and regain function in your injured knee. 
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what should I do now?
Doctor: I would recommend scheduling an appointment with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess your current condition and create a plan for your ongoing recovery.
Patient: Alright, I'll do that. Thanks for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and wishing you a speedy recovery.
document.prediction:
Subjective: The patient reports an electrical burn from a power line, resulting in 32% total body surface area third-degree injuries. The injury to the left knee involved an open joint injury, treated with three skin grafting procedures and placement of a spatial external fixator (SEF) for 8.5 weeks, which was locked in full extension. Post-sealage, the patient required additional grafts and a bony prominence resection. No significant complications were recorded during the SEF treatment. There are no PT/OT notes or follow-up recorded, indicating the absence of these sessions.
Assessment: Primary diagnosis is a left-knee open-joint injury with complications including a sphenoidal foreign body (SFO) placement and subsequent surgical interventions. Doctor: Hi, I understand you recently presented to an outside institution with an acute episode of aphasia. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, it was quite sudden. I had difficulty speaking and understanding what others were saying.
Doctor: I see. The MR-imaging that was performed revealed an enhancing left temporal mass, with a maximum enhancing diameter of 2.1 cm (Fig.). The biopsy of the lesion showed that it was histologically consistent with GBM. The test results were IDH1R132H negative, 1p/19q intact, MGMT unmethylated, p53 positive, and without EGFR amplification. 
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: To treat this, you underwent LITT, which involved an energy of 24.42 kJ, 876 pulses, and a time of 0:29:07. The treatment was done using a single track approximately 4 cm in length. You were discharged home on post-treatment day 2 at your neurological baseline. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: About two weeks after LITT, you came to our institution with complaints of increasing headache and calculation difficulties, despite being on corticosteroid therapy. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, the headaches were getting worse, and I had trouble doing simple math.
Doctor: I understand. The MR-imaging we did revealed tissue necrosis with hemorrhagic material within the LITT treated region and edema surrounding the treatment site. To address this, you underwent en bloc resection of the enhancing lesion and adjacent tumor-infiltrated brain via a left temporal craniotomy (Fig.). Your headache and calculation difficulties resolved after the surgery and you were discharged on post-operative day 2. 
Patient: Yes, I felt much better after the surgery.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Post-operative MR-imaging confirmed complete resection of the enhancing lesion. You also underwent adjuvant radiation therapy and were treated to a dose of 5945 cGy in 29 fractions with concurrent temozolomide. However, the maintenance temozolomide was discontinued after 5 cycles due to persistent pancytopenia.
Patient: Yeah, I remember that.
Doctor: Interestingly, there has been no surgical or medical treatment for the past 4 years, and serial MR imaging since the surgery has shown no recurrence

Doctor: Hello there, can you please tell me why you have come in today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm a 13-year-old boy and I've been experiencing headaches, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 weeks.
Doctor: I see. Let's take a closer look at your condition. We performed a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of your brain and spinal cord, which revealed a left cerebellar expansive lesion. However, there is no evidence of metastasis.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also conducted a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination, and fortunately, there is no evidence of dissemination. You underwent complete surgical resection as confirmed by postoperative imaging to remove the lesion.
Patient: So the surgery went well then?
Doctor: Yes, the surgery was successful. After that, we performed a histopathological analysis, including reticulin staining, which revealed a desmoplastic/nodular MB. There was no diffuse severe cytological anaplasia present.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: It means that the tumor is a specific type, and it's not as aggressive as some other types. We also performed complementary immunophenotypic characterization, which suggested a MB with SHH activation and TP53 wild-type. The nuclear INI-1 staining was preserved, and P53 immunostaining showed nuclear positivity only in a small proportion of the tumor cells.
Patient: Okay, I hope that's a good sign.
Doctor: Yes, it is. There was no evidence of MYCN or MYCC amplification by fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH). We conducted next-generation sequencing (NGS) over a panel of 50 genes using the Ion AmpliSeq

Comprehensive Cancer Panel, and it revealed IDH1 R132C mutation in 24% of cells, SMARCB1-R201G in 30% of cells, and CDH11-L625T in 26% of cells. The panel was tested on both tumor and normal tissue to confirm the somatic nature of the mutations

Doctor: Hello, I see that you're an 11-year-old female who presented to the emergency department and was admitted to the hospital in October 2016 with a 1-month history of extreme right lower extremity burning pain and seizure-like activity. We've tried treating your pain with several drugs, including Toradol, Motrin, Tylenol, Oxycontin, and even IV morphine. Have these medications provided any relief?
Patient: No, they haven't really helped with the pain or the seizures.

They suggested reflex sympathetic dystrophy, which was considered due to alterations in the color and temperature of your right leg and evidence of inflammation in the peri-knee ligaments. We've obtained informed consent to try ozone therapy using direct intravenous gas (DIV). We'll start with five treatments per week, for 26 weeks, totaling 120 treatments. You'll begin therapy at 5 cc gas at a concentration of 55 ¼g/cc and gradually increase to 30 cc at 55 ¼g/cc.

Patient: That would be a relief.
Doctor: After 3 months, the pseudoseizures should become rare, and by the 4th month, they should stop completely, along with the clearance of all pain. You should be able to return to school symptom-free 1 year after it began and remain symptom-free since.
