Doctor: Hi, I see from your history that you've had HTLV-1 infection for 20 years, along with coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes type-2, peripheral vascular disease, chronic neck and back pain, and you've been nonambulatory for a year. You were admitted to the medical service due to dehydration and acute kidney injury. How have you been feeling lately?
Patient: I've been feeling really weak and experiencing worsening pain in my legs. I also have this strange tingling sensation.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. We consulted neurology for your symptoms, and they performed a neurological examination to evaluate for HTLV-1 myelopathy, which can cause pain, stiffness, and gait problems. The examination showed a flat, mask-like face with a positive glabellar reflex. They also found decreased power bilaterally in your upper and lower extremities, brisk reflexes, and hypertonia. Can you tell me more about your muscle strength and any tremors you may have experienced?
Patient: Sure, my arm strength feels like it's 4 out of 5 and I've noticed some shaking when I try to do things. My leg strength is really low, maybe 2 out of 5.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. The examination also found brisk reflexes and bilateral clonus in your lower extremities, as well as bilaterally upgoing toes. The sensory examination was normal, but there was generalized diffuse rigidity. We performed some imaging tests, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of your brain, which showed bilateral basal ganglia calcifications and mild cortical atrophy. We also did magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain, which revealed low signal intensity from iron accumulation in the red nucleus and substantia nigra, as well as atrophy of the cerebral cortex and superior vermis of the cerebellum. The MRI of the thoracolumbar spine and magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) were unremarkable.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also tested your serum for HTLV-1 antibody, which was positive by enzyme immunoassay (EIA), and your glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD65) antibody was also positive at 8 IU/ml by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Based on the clinical evaluation, it appears that you have HTLV-1 related myelopathy with parkinsonism

Doctor: It looks like they performed a neurovascular assessment and didn't find any deficits, which is good. And they did an initial inspection of your leg to assess the wound. Did they do any treatment at that point?
Patient: Yes, they cleaned the wound with irrigation and gave me IV cefazolin, gentamicin, and penicillin. They also applied a splint to my leg.
Doctor: Good, those initial treatments are important. I see that you underwent intraoperative irrigation and debridement within the first 24 hours, and they placed a suprapatellar IMN. How did you feel after the surgery?
Patient: I was okay at first. They gave me two doses of IV Ancef, and I was discharged with a nonweightbearing status on my injured leg.
Doctor: I understand that you started to develop progressive knee discomfort over time. Can you describe the symptoms and when they began?
Patient: Yeah, after about four weeks, I started to have severe pain in my knee. It got really swollen and red, and I could hardly move it.

Patient: Yeah, that's when things started to get really serious.

Doctor: Hello, I have reviewed your case as the second patient. It seems that you have a history of hypertension and delirium. How has your blood pressure been lately?
Patient: Oh, it's been well controlled recently.
Doctor: That's good to hear. I also noticed that you're taking dementia medicine. Are you able to follow commands well?
Patient: Yes, I can follow commands without any problem.
Doctor: Great. We conducted a pulmonary function test, and the results indicated an obstructive pattern. Are you aware of this?
Patient: Yes, I remember being told about that.
Doctor: Alright. We performed a total hip arthroplasty using the same anesthetic regimen used for the first patient. During the surgery, while ventilating at an FiO2 of 0.4, you experienced hypoxia. Your O2 saturation level dropped from 100% to 80%, and your PaO2 dropped from 129 to 53.0. Do you remember any shortness of breath or discomfort during this time?
Patient: Hmm, I don't recall any specific feeling, but it was a bit uncomfortable at times.
Doctor: I see. We administered a muscle relaxant-reversing agent which helped you recover spontaneous respiration. Your O2 saturation level improved from 81% to 88%. We then applied continuous positive airway pressure, and your O2 saturation level further improved to 90%. After the surgery, your O2 saturation level increased to 98%. How are you feeling now?
Patient: I feel much better now, thank you.
Doctor: That's good to know. I want to inform you that neither you nor the first patient developed any respiratory complications after the surgery. The postoperative chest X-ray showed no notable findings for the first patient. However, in your case, it showed subsegmental atelectasis on the right middle lobe compared to the preoperative findings. We will monitor this closely and take necessary actions if needed. Please make sure to attend your follow-up appointments for further evaluation.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and see you at your follow-up appointment.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help. See you soon.

Doctor: Good morning, ma'am. How can I help you today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have been having intermittent acute abdominal pain and vomiting. It's been really uncomfortable.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. When was your last bowel movement?
Patient: It was 2 days ago, and I haven't passed any gas since then.
Doctor: Alright. Can you please tell me about your medical history? Do you have any known conditions or surgeries in the past?
Patient: Yes, I have arterial hypertension, and I had a laparotomic appendectomy when I was 12 years old.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Are you currently taking any medications?
Patient: I'm taking valsartan 80 mg daily for my hypertension.
Doctor: Okay. Let's check your vitals. Your body temperature is 37.5 °C, and all other vital parameters seem normal. I'm going to perform an examination to assess the pain you're experiencing. Please let me know if you feel any discomfort.
Patient: Sure, doctor.
Doctor: It seems like you have pain and localized peritonism in the lower right quadrant of your abdomen. We need to run some laboratory tests to get a better understanding of your condition.
Patient: Okay, doctor.
(After the tests)
Doctor: The laboratory tests show that your white blood cell count is elevated at 14,000 per microliter. Based on your symptoms and test results, we need to evaluate and treat you for possible conditions.
Patient: What could be the possible diagnosis, doctor?
Doctor: The working diagnosis includes several possibilities such as stump appendicitis, right colon diverticulitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, bowel obstruction, gastroenteritis, right renal colic, right colon cancer, bowel ischemia, or inflammatory bowel disease.
Patient: That's quite a list. How will you determine the exact issue?
Doctor: We will run some more tests and possibly perform imaging, like a CT scan, to narrow down the diagnosis and determine the best treatment plan for you.
Patient: Alright, doctor. Thank you for your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will do our best to identify the cause of your symptoms and ensure that you receive proper treatment. Please follow up with us after the tests, so we can discuss the results and move forward with your care.

Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. What brings you to the family medicine clinic today?

Patient: No, there hasn't been any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Has your child been in contact with anyone who's been sick recently?
Patient: No, he hasn't had any recent sick contact.
Doctor: I understand your child has seen several general practitioners for the same complaint, but no diagnosis was obtained. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Can you tell me about your child's past medical history? Any hospital admissions or surgeries?
Patient: He's had an unremarkable past medical history, with no hospital admissions or surgeries.
Doctor: Does your child take any medications or have any food or drug allergies?
Patient: No, he doesn't take any medications, and he doesn't have any known food or drug allergies.
Doctor: Was your child full term, and what was his birth weight?
Patient: Yes, he was full term, and his birth weight was 3.5 kg.
Doctor: How was the labor and delivery? Were there any complications?
Patient: The labor and delivery went smoothly, with no complications.
Doctor: Is your child up to date with his vaccination schedule?
Patient: Yes, he's up to date with his vaccinations.
Doctor: Have you had any parental concern regarding his development?
Patient: No, he's been reaching his developmental milestones on time, and we haven't had any concerns.
Doctor: What about your child's social history and family history? Any diseases running in the family or consanguineous marriage?
Patient: No, there's no history of diseases running in the family

Doctor: What treatment were you given for that?
Patient: I was started on an antituberculous regimen consisting of rifampicin (450 mg/day), ethambutol (800 mg/day), and clarithromycin (1000 mg/day) to cover possible atypical mycobacteria.

Doctor: What were the findings of the second examination?
Patient: My visual acuity was 6/12 in both eyes, and everything else appeared normal, including pupillary reactions. I underwent baseline perimetry which revealed central bitemporal hemianopia that respected the vertical midline, consistent with ethambutol toxicity.

Patient: Sure, I've been having blurry vision in my left eye and it's been affecting my daily activities.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. I can see from your records that you were diagnosed with bilateral AS and CNV secondary to AS in your left eye. You were treated with 12 intravitreal injections of ranibizumab over 13 months. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I also noticed that despite the intensive treatment with ranibizumab, there wasn't any significant functional or anatomic change. One month after the last administration, your best-corrected visual acuity was 10/10 in your right eye and remained stable at 3/10 in your left eye. Fundoscopy demonstrated the peau d'orange fundus appearance and AS as multiple irregular linear branching subretinal streaks. An elevated gray-yellow subretinal lesion compatible with CNV was observed in your left eye, adjacent to a large fibrotic lesion. Do you remember having a fluorescein angiography test done?
Patient: Yes, I remember having that test.
Doctor: The test clearly showed streaks around the optic disc and leakage of the dye originating from the CNV, while staining of the fibrotic element of the foveal lesion was observed. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging also revealed signs of active CNV in your left eye with intraretinal and subretinal fluid accumulation. At that point, it was agreed to switch your treatment to aflibercept, using the proposed treatment regimen for age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Do you recall signing an informed consent form for this new treatment?
Patient: Yes, I do remember signing the consent form.
Doctor: Great. You received a loading dose consisting of 3 consecutive intravitreal injections of aflibercept (2 mg [50 µL]) monthly, followed by bimonthly aflibercept administration at the same dose. How has your vision been since starting this new treatment?
Patient: Actually, I've noticed some improvement in my left eye

Doctor: Hello, I understand you have been diagnosed with kappa light chain multiple myeloma and ESRD. We have treated you with five cycles of CyBorD followed by high-dose cyclophosphamide mobilization and autologous HSCT with melphalan 140 mg/m2 therapy. How are you feeling now?
Patient: I've been feeling quite weak, and I recently had a fever.
Doctor: I see. It appears that you developed a neutropenic fever with Streptococcus sanguinis bacteremia. We have been treating you with vancomycin, cefazolin, and metronidazole for that infection. Have you had any history of liver disease?
Patient: No, I've never had any liver problems before.
Doctor: Your total serum bilirubin level was 3.4 mg/dl at the time of transplantation, and it peaked on treatment day 24 at 22 mg/dl. We performed imaging and discovered ascites, which is fluid in your abdominal cavity. We also conducted a liver biopsy on treatment day 16, which was consistent with SOS (sinusoidal obstruction syndrome).
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What are the next steps in my treatment?
Doctor: We have started treating you with ursodiol, a medication that helps protect the liver. Unfortunately, your condition has worsened, and we were hoping to get defibrotide for you under compassionate use. 
Patient: So, when can I start the defibrotide treatment?
Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that we were unable to secure the defibrotide in time. Your loved one passed away on treatment day 25. Our deepest condolences to you and your family.
Family Member: Thank you, Doctor. We appreciate all the efforts you and your team made to help him.

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing purpura, central obesity, facial plethora, and hypertension. I think I might have Cushing's syndrome.
Doctor: Based on your presentation, it is possible that you have Cushing's syndrome. We'll need to run some tests to confirm this.
Patient: Okay, what kind of tests?
Doctor: We'll check for ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome, which could be due to a pituitary tumor. In your case, your symptoms and test results confirmed ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome, likely of pituitary etiology. 
Patient: Oh wow, so what's the next step?
Doctor: The next step was a transsphenoidal surgery to remove the tumor. During your first surgery, the tumor was visualized but no sample was obtained for pathological analysis.
Patient: Yeah, I remember that. So what happened after that?
Doctor: With persistent postoperative hypercortisolism, a repeat transsphenoidal surgery was completed two months later. This time, a corticotroph adenoma was confirmed on pathology.
Patient: But I still felt off after the second surgery...
Doctor: Yes, you remained hypercortisolemic after the second surgery. One year later, we started you on cabergoline 1 mg twice weekly for persistent and moderately elevated 24-hour UFC levels.
Patient: Oh, I see. But I had to stop taking the medication for a while...
Doctor: At age 54, during a period of medication nonadherence, your 24-hour UFC increased to twice normal. Two months later, you presented to the hospital with a three-day history of worsening left lower quadrant abdominal pain.
Patient: Yeah, the pain was really bad.
Doctor: A CT scan of your abdomen showed a large collection of stool and gas centrally in the mesentery, on the background of multiple diverticulae. Surgery was needed to address this issue.
Patient: What did the surgery find?
Doctor: During the surgery, a 1.5 × 3 cm perforation of the sigmoid colon was found, with features more consistent with a perforated stercoral ulcer rather than a diverticular perforation. A distal sigmoidectomy with the creation of an end colostomy was performed.

Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling this weird pain in my lower abdomen, and there's a noticeable mass on the right side of my abdomen.
Doctor: I see. Do you remember when you first started experiencing this pain and noticed the mass?
Patient: I think it's been about a month or so since I first noticed it.
Doctor: Alright. Now, I also noticed in your past medical history that you had a right breast fibroid neoplasm removed 10 years ago. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I had surgery to remove it back then.
Doctor: Thank you for confirming that. We'll take this into consideration as we evaluate your current condition. Have you experienced any changes in your bowel habits, weight loss, or other symptoms that may be related to this mass and pain?
Patient: Not really, nothing major. Just this constant discomfort in my lower abdomen.
Doctor: Okay. I'd like to order some tests to help determine the cause of this mass and pain. This may include blood tests, imaging studies, and possibly a biopsy.
Patient: Alright, I understand.
Doctor: Once we have the results, we'll discuss the findings and determine the best course of action for your treatment. It's important to address this issue, as it could be related to your past history of fibroid neoplasm.
Patient: Yeah, I just want to figure out what's going on and get it taken care of.
Doctor: Absolutely. I'll make sure we get the necessary tests scheduled as soon as possible. In the meantime, please let me know if your symptoms worsen or if you experience any new symptoms.
Patient: Okay, I will. Thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll be in touch soon with more information and to schedule your tests. Take care, and I'll see you again soon.

Doctor: Hi there, I see you've presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain that's been going on for one night. This pain has been causing you difficulty with sleeping and walking, is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, that's right. It's been really hard to get any rest or move around.
Doctor: Have you experienced any loss of appetite, vomiting, or fever along with this pain?
Patient: No, I haven't lost my appetite or been vomiting, but I did have a fever earlier.
Doctor: I noticed that you had an appendectomy 19 months ago due to similar symptoms and were diagnosed with appendicitis. Were there any complications during or after that surgery?
Patient: No, there weren't any problems during or after the surgery.
Doctor: Have you had a bowel movement in the last few days?
Patient: Hmm, now that you mention it, I haven't had one for several days.
Doctor: When you first arrived, we performed a physical examination and found signs of fever and localized peritonitis. Your lab results showed leukocytosis of 13,300 per cubic millimeter, which is above the reference range of 4,500-13,000, and neutrophilia of 9,870 per cubic millimeter, also above the reference range of 1,700-7,500. Your C-reactive peptide was elevated at 1.4 milligrams per deciliter, with the normal range being below 0.5. After giving you antipyretics, your fever has reduced, but you're still experiencing severe abdominal pain.
Patient: That's correct, the pain is still really bad.

Doctor: Hello, I understand that you have a history of acute inflammatory demyelinating process and have recently been experiencing a mass in your left hand. Can you tell me more about when you first noticed it?
Patient: Yeah, about 3 months ago, I started feeling this mass on my left wrist and the hypothenar area of my hand. It's been getting more and more uncomfortable.
Doctor: I see. You were admitted to the hospital with generalized weakness, ataxia, and multiple sensory deficits, including a complete lack of sensation in your left small finger and the ulnar side of your hand. Can you tell me more about these symptoms?
Patient: Sure, I've been feeling really weak and unsteady, and I've lost all feeling in my left pinky and the side of my hand. It's been really difficult to do things with my left hand.
Doctor: We initially thought that the sensory deficits were related to your demyelinating disorder, but upon examination, we believe that the ulnar deficit is related to the mass in your hand. The mass is soft, nontender, and doesn't limit your range of motion. Your grip strength seems decreased compared to your other hand, though we haven't measured it objectively yet. Have you experienced any trauma, previous surgeries, or other masses in the past?
Patient: No, I haven't had any trauma or surgeries, and I've never had any other masses before.
Doctor: We've also done radiographs of your left upper extremity, which appeared normal. Our initial diagnosis is that the mass could be a lipoma. We conducted a magnetic resonance angiography of your left hand to get a better understanding of the mass, but its etiology is still unclear (Fig. ).
Patient: Hmm, so what's the next step, then?
Doctor: We performed an operative excision under general anesthesia to remove the mass. We made a longitudinally oriented ulnar-sided skin incision, dissected the palmar fascia, and released Guyon's canal. The mass was found to be arising from beneath the hypothenar musculature, and it appeared tan-white, rubbery, and lobulated (Fig. ).
Patient: What did the pathology report say?
Doctor: The pathology report confirmed that the mass is a benign myxoma (Fig. ). There were no postoperative complications, which is a good sign.

Doctor: Hello, I understand you're an 8-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with congenital heart disease during infancy, but had unknown follow-up and treatment. What brings you here today?
Patient: I've been feeling really tired and having trouble breathing when I'm playing with my friends. It started about a month ago.
Doctor: I see. When you were admitted to the hospital, we did a physical examination and found a systolic murmur in your left para-sternum. An echocardiography was also performed, revealing a peri-membranous VSD with a diameter of 12 mm, left to right shunting, and a pressure gradient of 20 mmHg. Additionally, we found a PDA with a diameter of 4 mm. 
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What did you do to treat it?
Doctor: First, we performed a trans-catheter PDA closure. Then, 3 weeks later, we did a TES for VSD repair without robotic assistance. During the procedure, you were placed in a supine position with your arms along your body, under general anesthesia with a single-lumen endotracheal tube.
Patient: What else did you do during the surgery?
Doctor: We used a no.6 Knitted Dacron graft to connect your right common FA with an end-to-side anastomosis. The other side of the graft was connected to the arterial line of the cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) machine. We also inserted SVC and IVC cannulae via your internal jugular vein (IJV) and femoral vein, respectively, using the Seldinger technique.
Patient: And then what happened?
Doctor: When we started the CPB, your arterial pressure gradually increased to 260 mmHg. So, we switched to bilateral FA cannulation by inserting an additional 10Fr FA cannula directly into your left common FA. After that, your arterial pressure declined and stabilized at 180-200 mmHg.
Patient: How did you perform the surgery?
Doctor: We placed four soft trocars in the right side of your chest to assist with the procedure.
Patient: I see. Thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. It's important that you understand your condition and the treatment you received. Please make sure to attend

Doctor: Hi there, I understand you've been brought to the emergency department due to sudden weakness and respiratory distress. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling?
Patient: Yeah, I suddenly felt really weak and it's hard to breathe. My consciousness feels confused too.
Doctor: I see. We've noticed that you have areflexic acute flaccid paralysis present on all four extremities. We've conducted some laboratory tests to better understand your condition. Your erythrocyte sedimentation rate is slightly elevated at 21 mm/h, compared to the average of 15 mm/h.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Your blood count, acetylcholine receptor antibody, thyroid function tests, and other laboratory findings are all within the normal range. However, there are no cells present in your cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and the CSF protein is high at 65 mg/dL.
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean, doc?
Doctor: These findings could suggest some sort of neurological issue. On the second day of your hospitalization, you developed bilateral peripheral facial paralysis. Additionally, nerve conduction studies showed a decrease in the sensory and motor action potentials of your upper extremities, with increased distal latencies.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: It is quite concerning. We also couldn't obtain any combined muscle action potential (CMAP) from your bilateral peroneal-tibial nerves or sural nerve sensory action potential. To help you, we decided to perform plasma exchange every other day, for a total of three times due to your respiratory distress.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Unfortunately, you developed resistant hypotension as an autonomic dysfunction, along with pulmonary infections. We tried our best to control the hypotension, but it persisted.
Patient: Oh no...
Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that your condition worsened and you experienced cardiac arrest on the sixth day of your hospitalization. Despite our efforts, we were unable to save you.
Patient's Family: We appreciate your efforts, doctor. We understand that you did everything you could. Thank you for trying.

[After tests and scan]

[After CT scan]
Doctor: The CT scan showed a dilatation of the ureter up to the vesicoureteric junction with an associated tight stricture. We'll need to perform a right rigid ureteroscopy, ureteric biopsy, and ureteric stent insertion to get a better understanding of the issue.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
[After procedure]
Doctor: The histology report from the biopsy shows that you have transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter. Initially, we didn't perform any neuroendocrine markers because the tumor didn't show any classical signs of a carcinoid tumor or a well-differentiated small cell carcinoma. However, further examination revealed an atypical carcinoid pattern.
Patient: Oh no, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We did some further imaging of your chest and fortunately, we didn't find any distant metastases. Our plan is to perform a right laparoscopic nephroureterectomy and open excision of the bladder cuff to remove the tumor.
Patient: I'm glad there's a plan in place. Let's do what needs to be done.
[After surgery]
Doctor: The surgery went well. The tumor in your ureter was about 18 mm long, and we were able to achieve a clear resection margin of at least 4 mm. Microscopy of the ureteric specimen showed a positive immunohistochemical stain with CD56, a common neuroendocrine marker. Staining with other neuroendocrine markers was weak

Patient: I moved and went to your sleep disorders center in 2004 with the same complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness. I wasn't on any specific treatment at that time.

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 19-year-old female and I recently got a dental implant. I went to my orthodontist because I was having some problems with it.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the complications you've experienced?
Patient: Well, my jaw has been hurting, and it feels like there's something wrong with the implant area.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We performed a biopsy to better understand what's going on, and it confirmed that you have central giant cell granuloma (CGCG) of the jaw.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What can we do about it?
Doctor: Don't worry, we've started you on a treatment called denosumab. You'll be receiving 120 mg monthly. It should help with your condition.
Patient: Okay, that's good to know. How will we keep track of my progress?
Doctor: We'll be conducting surveillance to monitor your condition. This will include imaging and a repeat biopsy at the 1-year treatment mark.
Patient: So, I'll have to wait a year to know if the treatment is working?
Doctor: Yes, we need to give the treatment time to show its effects. But we'll be keeping a close eye on your progress throughout this period.
Patient: Alright, I understand. Is there anything else I need to be aware of or do during this time?
Doctor: Just make sure to attend your monthly appointments for denosumab and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. We'll provide you with further instructions as needed.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll make sure to follow your advice.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and see you at your next appointment.
summarization.prediction:
Subjective: The patient is a 19-year-old female who recently received a dental implant and reports pain and discomfort in her jaw due to issues with the implant area. She went to her orthodontist after experiencing these symptoms.
Objective : A biopsy was performed, which confirmed the diagnosis of central giant cell granuloma (CGCG) of the jaw. The treatment has been initiated with 120 mg of denosumab monthly for the next year to monitor the disease's response to treatment. No other specific lab results or imaging data were provided during the consultation. 
Assessment: Primary diagnosis is recurrent jaw cancer, confirmed by biopsies. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of jaw cancers, but these are less likely given the specific nature and nature of this particular case. There is no immediate risk to the patient's health or her long-term health status, and the prognosis depends on the effectiveness of treatment and monitoring of her condition over the long term.
summarization.summarization:
Subjective: The patient is a 19-year-old female who presented with jaw pain and concerns about her recent dental implant. She reports that the pain is localized around the implant area.
Objective: A biopsy was performed, confirming the diagnosis of central giant cell granuloma (CGCG) of the jaw. The patient has been prescribed denosumab, with a dosage of 120 mg monthly.
Assessment: The primary diagnosis is central giant cell granuloma of the jaw, confirmed by biopsy. The patient has started treatment with denosumab, which is appropriate for managing CGCG.
Plan: The management plan includes monthly administration of denosumab 120 mg. Surveillance will be conducted to monitor the patient's condition, including imaging and a repeat biopsy at the 1-year treatment mark. The patient is advised to attend all monthly appointments and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further instructions will be provided as needed, and the patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

Doctor: Hi there, I understand you've come to the emergency department with some pain in your abdomen. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, for the past two days, I've had this pain in my stomach, and I haven't been feeling like eating. I've also been vomiting.
Doctor: I see. Based on your presentation, it's important that we conduct a thorough examination. Let me examine your abdomen.
Patient: Sure, go ahead.
Doctor: (After examination) It seems you have pain and tenderness on the right side of your abdomen. We'll need to run some clinical, laboratory, and radiological tests to determine the cause.
Patient: Okay, I hope it's nothing serious.
Doctor: (After tests) We've found that you've tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 through a PCR test of your nasopharyngeal swab. In addition, based on your symptoms and our examination, we suspect that you may have appendicitis.
Patient: Oh no, what will happen now?
Doctor: We will start you on an empiric intravenous antimicrobial treatment with cefotaxime and metronidazole to help fight the infection. Additionally, you'll need to undergo a laparoscopic appendectomy in the operating room to remove your appendix.
Patient: How soon will I have the surgery?
Doctor: We will take you to the operating room as soon as possible, as this is an emergency case.
Patient: Alright then, I hope everything goes well.
Doctor: Rest assured, our team will take good care of you. We perform appendectomies routinely, and we'll monitor you closely during the procedure and afterwards.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Patient: They injected some local anesthetic and made a small incision at the site of insertion. But they couldn't find the Nexplanon® right away. Plan: Plan to consult with a multidisciplinary team to discuss the best approach for managing the ulnar nerve injury and safely removing the Nexplanon®.

summarization.document:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I understand you have a history of CTEPH and are here for a PTE procedure. How are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, Dr. Smith. I'm a bit nervous but ready to get this done.
Doctor: I understand. During the rewarming process following your PTE, we noticed bright red blood in your airway. We performed a bronchoscopy and found that there was bleeding from your right lung.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds scary.
Doctor: It was concerning, but we attempted to control the bleeding by placing a right-sided Arndt endobronchial blocker. Unfortunately, due to copious bleeding, our first attempt was unsuccessful.
Patient: What happened next?
Doctor: We exchanged your 8.0 mm single lumen ETT for a 9 mm single lumen ETT. Then, we were able to successfully place a right-sided 9Fr Arndt endobronchial blocker with the aid of a 6.0 mm outer diameter therapeutic bronchoscope. This helped contain the bleeding.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: We continued weaning you off the cardiopulmonary bypass, and everything went well. You were then transferred to the ICU for close monitoring.
Patient: So, what's next for me?
Doctor: Unfortunately, your postoperative course has been complicated by renal failure, reintubation for hemoptysis, and poor neurologic recovery. Due to these multiple complications, we have been discussing the best course of action with your family.
Patient's family: Doctor, what options do we have for him?
Doctor: At this point, we are considering initiating comfort only measures to ensure that he is as comfortable as possible during this difficult time.
Patient's family: We understand. We want him to be comfortable.
Doctor: I'm sorry to say, but despite our best efforts, the patient expired on postoperative day 20. Our condolences to the family, and we will continue to provide support as needed.
summarization.prediction: Subjective: The patient, with a history of CTEPH, reported feeling nervous before the PTE procedure. Postoperative complications included renal failure, reintubation for hemoptysis, poor neurologic recovery, and the patient's death on postoperative day 20 despite multiple attempts. The family expressed understanding and support during this difficult time.
summarization.summarization:
Subjective: The patient, with a history of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), presented for a pulmonary thromboendarterectomy (PTE). He reported feeling nervous but ready for the procedure. Postoperatively, he experienced complications including renal failure, reintubation for hemoptysis, and poor neurologic recovery.
Objective: During the rewarming process post-PTE, bright red blood was noted in the patient's airway. A bronchoscopy revealed bleeding from the right lung. Initial attempts to control the bleeding with a right-sided Arndt endobronchial blocker were unsuccessful due to copious bleeding. The patient's 8.0 mm single lumen endotracheal tube (ETT) was exchanged for a 9 mm ETT, and a right-sided 9Fr Arndt endobronchial blocker was successfully placed with the aid of a 6.0 mm outer diameter therapeutic bronchoscope. The patient was weaned off cardiopulmonary bypass and transferred to the ICU for close monitoring.
Assessment: The primary diagnosis is postoperative complications following PTE in a patient with CTEPH. These complications include acute renal failure

summarization.document:
Doctor: Hi there! I see you recently presented 2 weeks after an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy for non-perforated acute appendicitis. How have you been feeling since the surgery?
Patient: Well, I've been having some issues with my urinary frequency. It's reduced to just twice per day and I'm experiencing prolonged hesitancy.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe your micturition stream for me?
Patient: Initially, it was weak and slow, but now it has become interrupted. Straining doesn't seem to help make the stream stronger.
Doctor: Alright. Have you ever suffered from urinary tract infections (UTIs) or constipation before?
Patient: No, I've never had any UTIs or constipation. I usually open my bowels daily.
Doctor: I understand you also had an episode of acute cystitis 2 months later. How was that treated?
Patient: I completely lost my ability to void, so I was put on an indwelling Foley urinary catheter. My cystitis was successfully treated with antibiotics.
Doctor: And what happened after the catheter was removed?
Patient: After every attempt to remove it, I had to be catheterized again, and they registered between 300 to 1200 mL of urine volume.
Doctor: How did that make you feel?
Patient: I lost the urge to urinate and only felt a dull pain in the suprapubic region and right iliac fossa when my bladder was extremely distended.
Doctor: I see you were referred to a tertiary center to determine the cause of your urinary retention. What were the results of your examinations?
Patient: They examined me and found normal clinical findings. They also did an abdominal and pelvic ultrasound scan but didn't find any obvious pathology. A pediatric neurologist checked me out and found nothing abnormal.
Doctor: Did they perform any additional tests, like magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), electromyography (EMG), somatosensory-evoked potentials (SEP) of the tibial nerve, electroencephalogram (EEG), or a lumbar puncture?
Patient: Yes, they did all of those tests, but they still didn't find any pathology.
Doctor: What about any gynecological examinations?
Patient: The gynecologist found multiple follicular cysts on my ovaries

She describes her micturition stream as weak and slow, now interrupted, with no improvement post-surgery and describes a loss of urge to urinate and dull pain in the suprapubic region and right iliac fossa when her bladder distended. No history of urinary tract infections (UTIs) or constipation, and she usually opens her bowels daily except for an episode of acute cystitis treated with Foley catheter and antibiotics two months later. Post-catheterization, her urinary volume fluctuated between 300 and 1200 mL, leading to ongoing urinary retention. Cystic fibrosis was noted on her ovaries with multiple follicular cysts on the left ovary, which were biopsied and biopsy results were negative.
Objective : Physical examination at a tertiary center showed normal clinical findings. Abdominal and pelvic ultrasound scans were normal. Additional tests including MRI, EMG, somatosensory-evoked potentials of the tibial nerve, electroencephalogram

Subjective: The patient, who underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy for non-perforated acute appendicitis two weeks ago, reports decreased urinary frequency (twice per day) with prolonged hesitancy, weak and interrupted micturition stream, and no improvement with straining. The patient denies previous history of urinary tract infections or constipation and reports daily bowel movements. Post-appendectomy, the patient experienced acute cystitis treated with antibiotics and required repeated catheterization due to inability to void, with urine volumes ranging from 300 to 1200 mL. The patient also reports loss of the urge to urinate and dull pain in the suprapubic region and right iliac fossa when the bladder is extremely distended.

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm experiencing sudden epigastric pain, and I feel like I'm in shock.
Doctor: I see. In that case, let me check your vital signs. We need to find out what's causing this shock. Have you had any recent medical issues?
Patient: Yes, I was hospitalized a month ago in your department and underwent a patch repair for a gastric ulcer perforation.
Doctor: Alright, let's perform a contrast-enhanced CT scan to get more information. 
(After CT scan)
Doctor: The CT scan revealed a retroperitoneal hematoma in your pancreatic head, aneurysm formation in the PDA, and extraluminal compression to the celiac trunk. Extravasation was also detected around the aneurysm in the PDA, but no liquid was retained in your peritoneal cavity.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What should we do?
Doctor: We will perform an emergent IVR for hemostasis to address the retroperitoneal hemorrhage from the ruptured PDA aneurysm. Arteriography of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) will be done through a sheath introduced in your right femoral artery.
Patient: Okay, go ahead.
(After the procedure)
Doctor: The imaging of the SMA revealed the development of several collaterals in your pancreatic head, and the common and proper hepatic arteries were imaged via these collaterals. The aneurysm in your PDA had leakage of the contrast-enhanced agent with a diameter of 9.3 mm. We have completed the IVR hemostasis by performing PDA coil embolization.
Patient: So, what's next?
Doctor: We will conduct SMA arteriography to see the other collaterals perfusing your proper hepatic artery. After the IVR therapy, we will monitor your blood chemical analysis for several weeks to ensure that your transaminase level is not elevated and hepatic infarction is negative.
Patient: Got it. And what about the obstruction caused by the hematoma?

Objective: Vital signs were taken, though specific values are not provided. Doctor: Hi there, I understand you're a 13-year-old girl who has been experiencing abdominal pain and bloody stool. Can you tell me more about how long this has been happening and how it's been progressing?
Patient: Yeah, I started having abdominal pain about 3 months ago. At first, it wasn't too bad and would come and go, so I didn't see a doctor. But lately, the pain has gotten worse, and I've been having bloody stool more often.
Doctor: I see. We performed an imaging study and it showed that there's a mass, including a fecalith, occupying your pelvic and right lower abdominal cavity (Fig.). Based on this, we made a preoperative diagnosis of an acute appendicitis with an appendiceal mass (Fig.). We've already done drainage of the abscess and an appendectomy.
Patient: Oh, okay. So what did you find during the procedure?
Doctor: Although the body of your appendix looked intact, as well as your ileum and cecum, the histopathological examination revealed PAA in the tip of the resected appendix. Because of this, we have planned a radical operation for the residual tumor of PAA in your pelvic cavity.
Patient: What does that operation involve?
Doctor: It involves a whole mass resection and ileocecal resection with lymph node dissection. Doctor: Hello, I understand you have been monitored at a neurology clinic and were referred to our clinic due to sustained hemifacial pain on the right side. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. The pain has been bothering me for a while now.
Doctor: I also noticed that you have been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2. Is it under control?
Patient: Yes, I've been managing it well.
Doctor: That's good to hear. I have reviewed your anterior rhinoscopic and endoscopic nasal examination results, and there were no pathological findings. However, your nasal septum is deviated to the left. Your hematological and biochemical parameters are normal, which is a good sign.
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what's causing the pain then?
Doctor: We performed a paranasal computed tomography (PNCT) imaging, and it revealed concha bullosa variation of the bilateral middle turbinates, and soft tissue density in the right concha bullosa. We then incised the concha bullosa by applying topical anesthesia to your right nasal cavity and performed a punch biopsy.
Patient: Hmm, and what did the pathology report say?
Doctor: The pathology report concluded that there were fungal hyphae and necrobiotic material. So, we prepared you for surgery. After receiving your written consent, we planned an endoscopic sinus surgery under general anesthesia.
Patient: I remember that. How did the surgery go?
Doctor: The surgery went well. We excised the lateral and inferior lamellae of the concha bullosa and submitted the infected material inside for pathologic examination. We controlled the bleeding, and the intervention was finalized.
Patient: That's a relief. What was my post-operative treatment?
Doctor: We prescribed a nasal wash and anti-inflammatory treatment for you. The pathological examination report revealed fungal organisms and their hyphae in the necrobiotic material. An advanced microbiological examination cultured "Aspergillus oryzae" through sequential analysis of the ribosomal DNA genes in the aspirated material.
Patient: So, how am I doing now?
Doctor: During your post-operative 6-month follow-up, we observed that your headache complaints were diminished and your nasal passage was open. It seems like the surgery and treatment have been successful.
Patient: That's great

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some difficulty breathing and mild chest pressure for about a week now. It reminds me of the symptoms I had when I had a pulmonary embolism more than 10 years ago.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of peripartum cardiomyopathy, mitral regurgitation, and hypertension.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Were you referred to the emergency department due to your severely elevated blood pressure?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Have you been taking any medications to manage your hypertension?
Patient: I was prescribed hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ), but I stopped taking it three days ago because it was causing increased urinary frequency. I've been maintaining compliance with losartan, though.
Doctor: Okay, let's go over your vital signs at presentation. Your temperature was 37.2 °C, BP was 218/150, heart rate 121, respiratory rate 16, and pulse oximetry was 100% on room air. Upon examination, your lungs were clear to auscultation, and you had no S3, jugular vein distention, or lower extremity edema. The remainder of your physical exam was unremarkable.
Patient: Hmm, I see.
Doctor: We also conducted some further tests, including labs, an electrocardiogram (EKG), a chest radiograph, and a bedside echocardiogram (BSE) performed by ultrasound trained EPs. Your initial troponin levels were mildly elevated at 0.08 µg/L, but they down-trended to 0.05 µg/L.
Patient: What does that mean?

Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. What brings you to the ER today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I fell and hurt my lower back. It's really painful.
Doctor: I see. Let's check your vital signs first. Your blood pressure is 159/91 mmHg, heart rate is 77 bpm, body temperature is 36.5°C, respiratory rate is 12/min, and your SpO2 is 100% on ambient air. Those numbers look mostly fine, but your blood pressure is a bit high. We'll keep an eye on that. Now, can you tell me more about your lumbago?
Patient: Well, it started right after I fell. It's a sharp pain in my lower back, and it's making it difficult to move around.
Doctor: I understand. We'll perform a Roentgenography and CT scan to get a better look at your lumbar area. Please wait for a moment while we get the results.
(After the tests)
Doctor: The results show that you have a compression fracture of your Th12 vertebra. The AIS score is 3, and your RTS is 7.8408, with a Ps of 0.99416.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the fracture is relatively stable, and the injury severity is moderate. Fortunately, conservative therapy is suitable for your condition. We'll provide you with a medical corset to help support your back during the healing process.
Patient: How long will it take for me to recover?
Doctor: You'll need to wear the corset for a few weeks, and you should avoid any heavy lifting or strenuous activities during that time. You'll be discharged on day 17 of your hospitalization. It's important to follow up with your primary care doctor to monitor your progress.
Patient: Okay, I understand. I'll be careful and follow your advice.
Doctor: That's great. With proper care and rest, you should fully recover from your injury in about 37 months.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'm relieved to hear that I'll eventually get better.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns during your recovery, don't hesitate to reach out to your primary care doctor or come back to the ER. Take care and get well soon.
Patient: Thanks, Doctor

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I recently had a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy to treat a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. I'm here for a follow-up.
Doctor: I see. How have you been feeling since the surgery?
Patient: In the immediate postoperative period, I developed a pancreatic fluid leak from the tail of my pancreas, and an abdominal drain was placed.
Doctor: Did the leakage stop after the drain was placed?
Patient: Yes, it stopped draining eventually, and the drain was removed.
Doctor: Were there any further complications after the drain removal?
Patient: Actually, yes. A month after the drain removal, a CT scan showed an increase in the size of the rim enhancing fluid collection around the tail of my pancreas.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Did you undergo any further procedures to address this issue?
Patient: Yes, an ERCP was performed for the suspected pancreatic duct leak, and it confirmed a leak from the tail of my pancreas.
Doctor: What was the next step in your treatment?
Patient: The doctor performed an endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy and placed a 5 Fr x 13 cm pancreatic duct stent with internal barbs.
Doctor: Good. And did you have any additional imaging done after that procedure?
Patient: Yes, an EUS showed a well-demarcated, hypoechoic, heterogeneous collection adjacent to the tail of the pancreas, about 6.5 cm in the largest dimension.
Doctor: How was this collection addressed?
Patient: The doctor placed a 15 mm x 10 mm LAMS under endosonographic guidance from my stomach into the fluid collection, and a large amount of pus was drained.
Doctor: It sounds like the procedure was successful. Did you have any follow-up scans to check the progress?
Patient: Yes, a CT scan of my abdomen a month later showed a decrease in the size of the previously demonstrated LUQ rim-enhancing fluid collection.
Doctor: That's a positive sign. Were there any other complications or events following the CT scan?
Patient: Unfortunately, I had a neurological event before the stent could be removed, which led to my current condition.
Doctor: I'm very sorry to hear that

Doctor: Hello, I understand you had a laryngectomy and free flap reconstruction 20 years ago and have been using a prosthesis since then. Can you tell me what happened recently?
Patient: Yeah, doc. I was cleaning my prosthesis when it suddenly dislodged and I think I aspirated it.
Doctor: I see. How did you feel when that happened?
Patient: I started feeling really short of breath and needed supplemental oxygen just to maintain my saturations above 90%. So, I went to the hospital.
Doctor: It seems like you initially presented to an outside hospital. They did a CT chest which demonstrated a radiopaque foreign body in your right mainstem bronchus. That's why they transferred you to our emergency department for a higher level of care. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Our otolaryngology service evaluated you in the emergency department. We performed a bedside flexible bronchoscopy using an Olympus BF-H190 bronchoscope after applying topical lidocaine spray. We found the aspirated prosthesis in your right mainstem bronchus.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: We were able to remove the prosthesis atraumatically by grasping it with flexible biopsy forceps and then withdrawing the entire bronchoscope. There were no other injuries or remaining foreign bodies. Did you feel any relief after that?
Patient: Yes, doc. I felt immediate relief after the procedure.
Doctor: That's great to hear. We placed a red rubber catheter through your tracheoesophageal puncture to stent the tract. You were then discharged home. You have a follow-up appointment with your speech-language pathologist (SLP) for prosthesis replacement the next day. Please ensure you attend that appointment.
Patient: Sure, doc. Thank you so much for your help.

Objective: Initial evaluation at an outside hospital revealed a radiopaque foreign body in the right mainstem bronchus on CT chest. At our facility, a bedside flexible bronchoscopy performed by the otolaryngology service using an Olympus BF-H190 bronchoscope and topical lidocaine spray confirmed the presence of the aspirated prosthesis in the right mainstem bronchus. The prosthesis was successfully removed atraumatically using flexible biopsy forceps. Post-procedure, no injuries or remaining foreign bodies were noted.
Assessment: The primary diagnosis is aspiration of a tracheoesophageal prosthesis. The successful removal of the prosthesis without any complications indicates a positive immediate outcome. There is no evidence of additional complications such as infection or significant mucosal injury at this time.

Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. I understand that you've been referred for a psychiatric evaluation by your daughter and the hospital staff due to your hallucinations and thoughts of suicide. Can you tell me more about your situation?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I'm a 55-year-old divorced, multiparous Caucasian woman. My hallucinations started about four months ago. At first, I heard a young girl and a rodent in my house. Then I started experiencing visual and tactile hallucinations of scabies crawling out of my skin.
Doctor: I see. And these hallucinations of scabies led you to believe that you had delusional parasitosis?
Patient: Yes, that's right. It got so bad that I began picking at my skin and applying bleach, ammonium-based cleaning products, and scabicidal agents to try to get rid of them. I even have self-inflicted excoriation and burn injuries on my face, extremities, and abdomen because of it.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. It must have been very distressing for you. How did your daughter come to the realization that you were experiencing a delusion?
Patient: Well, I thought three men had broken into my home intending to harm me and my daughter. But she realized it was a delusion and brought me to the community hospital for assessment.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. It's important for us to understand the events leading up to your psychiatric evaluation. Have you tried seeking help from dermatologists regarding your parasitic delusions?
Patient: Yes, I have. I even claimed to have proof of parasitic specimens collected from my body that I could see under a magnifying glass, but the dermatologists were unable to confirm my findings.
Doctor: That must have been frustrating. At any point, were you able to communicate with the parasitic delusions?
Patient: Yes, eventually, I started to talk to the scabies because I couldn't get rid of them, and they seemed to acquire personalities.
Doctor: It sounds like you've been through a lot. Can you tell me more about the persecutory delusions and intrusive thoughts you've experienced?
Patient: I've had thoughts that I should swallow objects, but thankfully, I've been able to dissuade myself from doing so.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Have you noticed any changes in your concentration, memory, or mood over the past six months?

Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having blurred vision, hyperemia, and pain in my right eye.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any fever, asthenia, anorexia, arthralgia, myalgia, ulcers, abdominal pain, lower back pain, or urinary symptoms?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Okay, based on your symptoms and some tests, we've diagnosed you with bilateral nongranulomatous anterior uveitis without additional complications. We also found that you have hypertension and raised levels of inflammatory markers, such as C-reactive protein at 2.6 mg/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 96 mm/first hour. Your glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is 48 ml/min/1.73m2, and you have hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, leukocyturia, glucosuria, hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, and raised urine ²2-microglobulin levels.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What about other infections?
Doctor: We've ruled out Hepatitis B and C, toxoplasmosis, brucellosis, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), and cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Your chest X-ray images are normal, and your angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) levels are normal. You're also negative for antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA).
Patient: What about my kidneys?
Doctor: Ultrasound imaging showed that your kidneys are slightly enlarged. We performed a kidney biopsy, which showed diffuse mononuclear cell interstitial infiltrates, consistent with acute tubulointerstitial nephritis.
Patient: So, what's the treatment plan?
Doctor: We've prescribed ocular dexamethasone and mydriatics for your eye, as well as oral prednisolone (5 mg/m2/day), amlodipine, and potassium citrate for your other conditions. Your blood pressure, serum creatinine, and tubular function should normalize, and you should be in remission from uveitis within three months.
Pat

Doctor: Hello, I just wanted to inform you about your son's situation after the accident. He was presented to the emergency department following a high-speed front-end collision with another vehicle. Was he the one driving?
Family: No, he was in the front seat but not driving. He was restrained, thankfully.
Doctor: I see. The vehicle he was in was struck head-on. Do you happen to know the speed at the time of the collision?
Family: We were told it was in excess of 79 miles per hour.
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. When your son arrived at the hospital, he was unconscious and not breathing independently. Our team attempted intubation at the scene, but unfortunately, it was unsuccessful.
Family: Oh no... So what happened next?
Doctor: Sadly, your son was pronounced dead soon after arrival to the hospital. Our deepest condolences to your family.
Family: Thank you, Doctor. This is so difficult for us. What were the findings from the radiographs?
Doctor: The radiographs at the time of the incident noted internal decapitation with AO assimilation specifically between the anterior arch of the atlas and the basiocciput. No fractures were noted, including the odontoid process.
Family: Did he have any past medical or surgical history that could have contributed to this?
Doctor: There was no known past medical or surgical history, and the AO assimilation was unknown to your family. The severity of the collision was the primary factor in this tragic outcome.
Family: We had no idea about the AO assimilation. Thank you for explaining everything to us, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or need any support, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. Our thoughts are with you and your family during this difficult time.

Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having abdominal pain for about 2 weeks now, and it's been getting worse. I also noticed some bleeding in my stool.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, fever, or weight loss recently?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Do you have any personal history of medical or surgical diseases? And is there any history of malignant disease in your family?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of medical or surgical diseases, and there's no history of malignant disease in my family either.
Doctor: Okay, let's do an initial clinical observation. *After examining the patient* You appear to be haemodynamically stable. I can feel a painless mass in your periumbilical region, left hypochondrium, and left flank. There's also evidence of low gastrointestinal bleeding, or hematochezia. We'll need to get some tests done to find the cause.
Patient: Alright, what tests do I need?
Doctor: First, let's check your haemoglobin. *After checking* Your initial haemoglobin value at admission is 133 g/dl. We'll also perform an emergency non-total colonoscopy to look for any gastrointestinal lesions that could cause the bleeding.
Patient: Okay, let me know what you find.
Doctor: *After colonoscopy* We didn't find any lesions during the colonoscopy. We'll need to perform an Angio-CT to get more information. *After Angio-CT* The scan showed a large exophytic mass, approximately 20 x 14 x 13 cm, arising from the 4th duodenal segment and first jejunal segment. It has vascularization provided from branches of the upper mesenteric artery, with vascular dilatations inside the tumor and apparent intratumoral bleeding. However, there's no intraperitoneal bleeding.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What are my options?
Doctor: Unfortunately, your condition has deteriorated, and you've become haemodynamically instable with a new episode of low gastrointestinal bleeding. Your haemoglobin value has dropped to 8.6 g/dl, so we'll need to provide fluid resuscitation and blood transfusion.
Patient: I understand.

Patient: Yes, it's been really difficult to deal with.
Doctor: I understand you were diagnosed with right-sided, multicentric, infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the breast 10 years ago. This was dilated using a through-the-scope controlled radial expansion (CRE) balloon, without fluoroscopic guidance. Biopsy of the gastric stenosis revealed gastric mucosa of antral type with minimal chronic inactive gastritis. No morphologic evidence of a Helicobacter pylori infection was detected. Did your symptoms of nausea and vomiting improve following balloon dilation?
Patient: Yes, they did improve after that.
Doctor: Good to hear. You were discharged on a daily proton pump inhibitor. Now, you underwent an endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) 12 weeks later. Gastric stenosis was found at the pylorus and duodenal bulb, which was dilated again with a CRE balloon to a maximum dilation of 13.5 mm. Do you recall this?
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: The EUS also showed diffuse wall thickening of the antrum of the stomach, with the gastric wall measuring up to 11 mm

Patient: Hi, I have Crouzon syndrome and I've been having multiple episodes of epistaxis in the past few days. I also have nasal obstruction and impaired nasal breathing for the past few months.
Doctor: I see. Do you have any other medical history we should be aware of?
Patient: No, the rest of my medical history is free.
Doctor: Alright, let's start with a clinical examination. *Examines patient* I notice a polypoid lesion protruding from your right nostril, asymmetry of your face, and projection of the ipsilateral canine fossa.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: We'll need to perform a computed tomography of your paranasal sinuses to get a clearer picture of what's going on. *Reviews CT results* The CT shows an inhomogeneous soft-tissue mass that completely occupies your right nasal cavity, maxillary sinus, and anterior and posterior ethmoidal cells. The lesion has caused extensive bone remodeling of your right maxillary sinus with complete absence of its anterior wall, erosion of the posterior wall, and entry of the lesion in the pterygopalatine fossa. There's also erosion of the ipsilateral lower and median orbital wall, and entry of the lesion in the orbital cavity. Despite its large size, the lesion seems to be well-defined without invasive characteristics.
Patient: That sounds serious. What do the laboratory tests say?
Doctor: Your routine laboratory tests are within the normal range. We also had a preoperative maxillofacial consultation, which excluded pathology of odontogenic origin.
Patient: What's the next step, then?

summarization.summarization:
Subjective: Patient with Crouzon syndrome presents with multiple episodes of epistaxis over the past few days and chronic nasal obstruction with impaired nasal breathing for several months. No other significant medical history reported.
Objective: Clinical examination revealed a polypoid lesion protruding from the right nostril, facial asymmetry, and projection of the ipsilateral canine fossa. CT imaging showed an inhomogeneous soft-tissue mass occupying the right nasal cavity, maxillary sinus, and ethmoidal cells, with extensive bone remodeling and erosion but no invasive characteristics. Routine lab tests are within normal limits. Biopsy indicated nonspecific inflammation. Postoperative findings confirmed nasal polyposis with inflammation but no fungal invasion or macroscopic neighboring structure invasion.
Assessment: Primary diagnosis of extensive nasal polyposis secondary to Crouzon syndrome, complicated by significant structural changes in the nasal cavity and surrounding areas. Differential diagnosis initially included possible malignant or invasive pathology, which was ruled out by imaging and histopathological examination.
Plan: Surgical intervention was performed via lateral rhinotomy and medial maxillectomy, with complete removal of inflammatory tissue. Postoperative treatment includes short-term antibiotic and corticosteroid therapy
